A limit order is an order to buy or sell at a specific price or better. Limit orders are not guaranteed to execute.
Market order is immediately matched to the best available market price.

OCO Order: To place a Stop-Limit order (the Trigger Stop Price should be higher than Market Price for Buy order, and lower for Sell order), and a Limit Order (the Limit Price should be lower than Market Price for Buy order, and higher for Sell order) at the same time. When either of the order pairs is triggered, the other order will be canceled. And if either of the order pairs is canceled, the other order will be canceled too.
A Stop-Limit order is an order to buy or sell a coin once the price reaches a specified price.

"1. Alpha Trading supports both instant orders and limit orders. Therefore, Alpha Trading's total trading volume = Alpha's instant order volume + Alpha's limit order volume."
2. Instant order volume represents only a portion of the total on-chain DEX transactions, while limit orders are executed off-chain and their volume is calculated separately.

The total amount of tokens currently circulating across all networks. The data comes from CoinMarketCap. Please be aware of asset risks before you proceed.
The unique blockchain address where the token’s smart contract is deployed.
The timestamp when the token contract was created on the blockchain.

The theoretical total market value after all tokens are fully unlocked and released. <hl1>FDV = Total Supply × Token Price.</hl1> The data comes from CoinMarketCap. Please be aware of asset risks before you proceed.
The number of unique wallet addresses holding this token on the blockchain. A higher holder count generally indicates broader token distribution and stronger community engagement.
The official launch or listing time of the asset.

The amount of tokens available for trading, swapping, or providing liquidity directly on blockchain networks. Higher on-chain liquidity means users can trade with lower price impact and better execution on decentralized platforms.

The total market value of circulating tokens across all networks. <hl1>Market Cap = All-chain Circulating Supply × Token Price.</hl1> The data comes from CoinMarketCap. Please be aware of asset risks before you proceed

The total amount of tokens that will be issued across all networks after full release (including any tokens not yet unlocked or issued). The data comes from CoinMarketCap. Please be aware of asset risks before you proceed.
If order A is filled fully, order B will be placed.
A conditional order where the parent order triggers an opposite-side order (take-profit or stop-loss) upon execution. <hl1>See FAQ</hl1> for details on order amount.

Spot trading in Tokenized Stocks is provided exclusively by Binance Services Latinoamérica, S.A. de C.V. (BSL). By accessing this page and product, you acknowledge that you are under the jurisdiction of El Salvador and some products might not be offered in your jurisdiction, under the oversight of Binance Services Latinoamérica S.A. de C.V. You also acknowledge and agree that Binance will share information regarding Transactions with regulatory authorities, government agencies and fiat payment partners as necessary to comply with applicable legal, regulatory or contractual obligations. See our Privacy Notice<hl1>%1$s</hl1>. For more details, please refer to the <hl1>FAQs</hl1>. Information made available by BSL or its affiliates, whether through websites, apps or other materials, does not constitute investment advice, a recommendation, or an offer or solicitation to engage in any investment or trading activity. You trade entirely at your own initiative, based on your own assessment of risk and suitability. You should only proceed if you are prepared to sustain a total loss of your invested capital. Tokenized stocks may not be suitable for all users. If you are uncertain, you should seek independent financial advice. BSL, its partners and associates do not accept any responsibility for losses you may incur as a result of your trading activity. Qualifying Questions for Tokenized Stock Spot Trading. You must answer all questions correctly or you will not be able to proceed:
1. Are you aware that tokens representing Tokenized stocks may experience significant price volatility during weekends, off-market hours, or non-trading periods when the primary market is closed?

Yes, I am aware that Tokenized stocks may exhibit higher volatility during non-trading periods, including weekends or off-market hours, compared to traditional equities, due to factors such as reduced liquidity and market isolation.
No, I am not aware of this risk.
2. Are you aware that the price of a Tokenized stock may deviate from the price of the underlying stock and may not maintain a strict 1:1 peg?
Yes, I understand that Tokenized stock prices might deviate from the actual equity price for multiple reasons, including platform activity, market conditions or other external factors.
No, I believe Tokenized stocks always track the equity price exactly 1:1.

3. Do you understand and accept that Tokenized stocks do not confer ownership of the underlying asset, voting rights, dividends, or shareholder entitlements, and may carry significant risk including loss of principal?
Yes, I accept that Tokenized stocks do not represent legal title to the underlying asset and I bear full responsibility for any resulting losses.
No, I do not accept this.

"Binance Alpha features emerging digital assets which are not listed on the Binance Exchange and which are generally expected to have a low market capitalization and unique or novel characteristics. The inclusion of a digital asset as a Binance Alpha asset does not in any way imply, directly or indirectly, that such digital asset will be listed on Binance Exchange in future.
As digital asset prices can be volatile, the value of any investment that you make in Alpha Assets may go down or up and you may lose all or part of the value of the amount that you invest. Please note that in relation to Binance Alpha (i) the risk of loss of all or part of your investment is magnified with Binance Alpha assets as they are subject to increased price volatility (ii) by purchasing Alpha Assets, you are exposed to price slippage and blockchain fees, which can have a negative impact of the price of Alpha Assets (iii) Alpha Assets cannot be withdrawn from the Binance Exchange, and you will only be able to access Alpha Assets from your Alpha Account only.
You are solely responsible for your investment decisions. Binance will not in any circumstances be responsible or liable for any losses that you may incur arising directly or indirectly from an investment in Binance Alpha Assets."

MEV (Maximal Extractable Value) attackers manipulate asset prices by altering the sequence of transaction packaging on public network nodes. They insert transactions before and after yours, leading to potential financial losses.

The difference between the executed and expected trade price. A higher slippage tolerance increases the chance of a successful trade in volatile markets but may result in a price deviation from expectations.
Priority Mode determines the strategy for processing your order: either \"Success\" or \"Price\" first. Slippage and Est. Network Fee vary between modes.

The Rate varies between the 2 Priority Modes. The rate displayed on the trading page includes the Basic Rate, Network Fee, and Trading Fee (Service Fee). The rate updates when your input amount changes and also refreshes every 15 seconds if you do not proceed to the next step.

You acknowledge and agree that Binance is not a party singly or together with your counterparty to the P2P transaction. You also acknowledge and agree that you are sharing your personal information for identity verification purposes with your counterparty and not with Binance.

Your conduct of a P2P transaction with a counterparty will be deemed your agreement to provide required personal information for identity verification purposes to that counterparty in accordance with the applicable laws and regulations. Such information may be used to verify your identity, identify traces of money laundering, terrorist financing, fraud, and other financial crimes or for other lawful purposes.

In addition to providing such information, you agree to allow your counterparty to keep a record of that information in compliance with the applicable laws and regulations. You also authorize the counterparty to conduct necessary investigations directly or through a third party to verify your identity or protect you and/or the counterparty from financial crimes, such as fraud or other financial crimes, and to take necessary actions based on the results of such investigations, including but not limited to, sharing of your data and/or rejecting to conclude a P2P transaction with you.

The information your counterparty requires to verify your identity may include, but is not limited to, your name, surname, government-issued personal code, and/or date of birth, citizenship, email address, contact information, phone number, username, government-issued ID, and other information collected. When providing the required information for the purpose of user identity verification, you confirm and warrant that all information provided by you is true, complete, and accurate.

You also acknowledge and agree that your personal information may be disclosed by the counterparty to relevant regulatory authorities, law enforcement entities and/or other competent authorities when they are required by law or by court to disclose certain information about you or any engagement they may have with you.

You further acknowledge and agree that neither this text nor the platform or its extensions are intended to and can be evaluated as a justification for any kind of involvement of Binance in your P2P transaction with your counterparty whatsoever.

Disclaimer: Binance does not have any kind of involvement in your P2P transaction with your counterparty or in your collecting or sharing of information for identity verification purposes whatsoever. Thus, Binance shall not be held responsible with regards to how your personal data is used by the counterparty.

"Dear buyer, in order for us to assist you faster, please provide a video showing the entire login process to your bank account (please hide the password) and the payment transaction details sent to the seller. Make sure the date, time, account number, and name of the sender and recipient are displayed. Video must be recorded using another phone/camera and NO cut or edit is allowed. Note: Screen recording is NOT accepted. The video must has a bright and background with movements (such as cars moving/people moving around), a video with dark or stable background is NOT accepted and will be required to record again. Please provide this information within the next 2 hours, if you fail to provide the requested video within the given time, we will solve the appeal in the favour of your counterpart. Binance is not liable for any loss resulting from the transaction if users remain unresponsive during the appeal handling process. Thanks for your cooperation"

"Dear seller, in order for us to assist you faster, please provide a video showing the whole process of logging into your bank account (please hide passwords) and show the transactions on your bank account from the order date to today to prove that you have not received the payment from the buyer. Make sure the date, time, account number, and name of the sender and recipient are displayed. Video must be recorded using another phone/camera and NO cut or edit is allowed. Note: Screen recording is NOT accepted. The video must has a bright and background with movements (such as cars moving/people moving around), a video with dark or stable background is NOT accepted and will be required to record again. Please provide this information within the next 2 hours, if you fail to provide the requested video within the given time, we will solve the appeal in the favour of your counterpart. P2P Dispute: The buyer reported that the actual payment made differs from the order value.
Poor Trading Behavior: Performing actions, such as consecutive canceled orders, coin-locking, and/or self-trading.
P2P Dispute: The seller reported that a chargeback was initiated after the release of crypto.
P2P Dispute: The order was canceled after the buyer had processed the payment.
P2P Dispute: The seller claimed that they had released the cryptocurrency prior to receiving payment for the order.
Violation of P2P Transaction Policy: Marking orders as paid without making the payments.
P2P Dispute: Lack of timely response and cooperation during a dispute.
Violation of P2P Transaction Policy: Leaving a sensitive remark on a fiat payment transaction to the seller.
Violation of P2P Transaction Policy: Making payment from an account not matching your verified name.
Suspicious Activity: Abnormal trading behavior detected on your account.
P2P Dispute: Your funds are frozen due to an ongoing issue. Please check the relevant order and resolve any issues as soon as possible.
Violation of P2P Transaction Policy: Using abusive language towards other users or customer support representatives.
Violation of P2P Transaction Policy: Charging additional fees to trading partners.
Low Trading Performance: Not meeting P2P Merchant standards
Violation of P2P Transaction Policy: Exhibiting abnormal wash-trading/self-trading behavior.
Suspicious Activity: Irregular trading activity detected on your account.
Terms of Use: P2P services are currently unavailable for you. Please review our <highlight>policy</highlight> for further information.
Violation of P2P Transaction Policy: Offering off-site trading or using an unsupported payment method.
Violation of P2P Transaction Policy: Irregular adjustments of advertisement pricing.
Violation of P2P Transaction Policy: Providing incomplete payment method details on your advertisements.
Violation of P2P Transaction Policy: Publishing identical advertisements with the same parameters.

What are Cross and Isolated modes?

"Cross Margin Mode: All cross positions under the same margin asset share the same asset cross margin balance. In the event of liquidation, your assets full margin balance along with any remaining open positions under the asset may be forfeited. Isolated Margin Mode: Margin assigned to a position is restricted to a certain amount. If the margin falls below the Maintenance Margin level, the position is liquidated. However, you can add and remove margin at will under this method."

When a product matures and hits its target price, the system will automatically settle your principal and earnings into the corresponding crypto and start a new investment in the opposite direction of your original trade. The new investment’s target price and yield will strictly follow your preset criteria.

When a product matures and reaches its target price, the system will automatically settle your principal and earnings into the corresponding crypto and start a new investment in the opposite direction of your original subscription. The ratio will be updated daily to reflect the rewards earned from the staked ETH. As ETH staking rewards accumulate, 1 WBETH gradually increases in value relative to 1 ETH.

When your staking is successful, WBETH, a tokenized representation of your staked ETH will be distributed to your Spot Wallet. The WBETH amount you receive is based on the official WBETH:ETH conversion ratio.

WBETH represents the staked ETH plus the staking rewards. Due to the accumulation of staking rewards, the value of 1 WBETH progressively exceeds that of 1 ETH. The WBETH:ETH conversion ratio is updated on a daily basis to reflect the reward accrued and value of WBETH versus ETH. The ETH staking APR is dynamic, following the onchain Ethereum staking rewards. A %1$s commission fee on the reward is charged to ensure the product is sustainable.

You can redeem WBETH for ETH based on the WBETH:ETH conversion ratio at redemption. Please note that there may be quota restrictions and a waiting period between when you submit a redemption request and when you receive the redeemed ETH. This is because ETH Staking is designed on the Ethereum mainnet, where only a limited daily quantity of ETH can be redeemed.
Your WBETH will be still entitled to staking rewards even when it is used in other Binance products or external DeFi applications.

ETH Staking is designed on the Ethereum mainnet, where only a limited daily quantity of ETH can be redeemed. You can redeem your BETH back to ETH if the daily quota allows. Please note that if the daily quota is used up, you may not be able to redeem your BETH to ETH and will have to wait for the next time the quota is open again.
There will be a waiting period before you receive the related ETH quantity in your Spot Wallet and the frozen BETH is deducted.
After the frozen BETH is deducted, you will need to wait for %1$s days. The redeemed ETH will then be deposited into your spot wallet.
After you successfully submit your WBETH redeem request, your WBETH will be frozen in your Spot Wallet, and you will not be able to receive rewards.

ETH Staking is designed on the Ethereum mainnet, where only a limited daily quantity of ETH can be redeemed. You can redeem your WBETH back to ETH if the daily quota allows. There will be a waiting period before you receive the related ETH quantity in your Spot Wallet and the frozen WBETH is deducted. Please consider the risk related to the value of both ETH and WBETH fluctuations.

After the frozen WBETH is deducted, you will need to wait for %1$s days. The redeemed ETH will then be deposited into your spot wallet. Please be aware of the risk of value fluctuation between ETH and WBETH.

By enabling auto-repayment, Binance will automatically repay your Fixed Rate Loan on the Expiry Date using assets from your Spot Wallet and then Earn Flexible Assets, if sufficient funds are available. If not, the auto-repayment will fail.
"You don't have enough assets for this repayment."

Binance Fixed Rate Loans are fixed-term loans. If you repay early, the pre-deducted interest is still fully payable and non-refundable. Repayment will use assets from your Spot Wallet and then Earn Flexible Assets, if sufficient funds are available. If not, the repayment will fail.

Subscription and redemptions for Simple Earn Locked Products are open daily between 00:10 to 23:50 (UTC+0).

For selected Locked Products, you can redeem your assets anytime before maturity and the redemption process is not reversible once confirmed. However, early redemptions will result in a loss of all rewards you have received. You will receive the full balance of your locked assets, minus any rewards you have received during the term, into your Spot Wallet within the next 72 hours. In the event of extreme market volatility, network delays, or when there is an unusually large number of redemption requests, your redemptions might be delayed.

For selected Locked Products, you can redeem your assets anytime before maturity and the redemption process is not reversible once confirmed. However, early redemptions will result in a loss of all rewards you have received and accrued. You will receive the full balance of your locked assets, minus any rewards you have received during the term, into your Spot Wallet within the next 72 hours. In the event of extreme market volatility, network delays, or when there is an unusually large number of redemption requests, your redemptions might be temporarily delayed.

When your staking is successful, BNSOL, a tokenized representation of your staked SOL will be distributed to your Spot Wallet. The BNSOL amount you receive is based on the official BNSOL:SOL conversion ratio.

BNSOL represents the staked SOL plus the staking rewards. Due to the accumulation of staking rewards, the value of 1 BNSOL progressively exceeds that of 1 SOL. The BNSOL:SOL conversion ratio is updated per Epoch on Solana network (approximately 2-3 days) to reflect the rewards accrued and value of BNSOL versus SOL. The SOL staking APR is dynamic, following the onchain Solana staking rewards. A %1$s commission fee on the reward is charged to ensure sustainability.

You can redeem BNSOL for SOL based on the BNSOL:SOL conversion ratio at redemption. Please note that there may be processing restrictions and a waiting period of %1$s days between when you submit a redemption request and when you receive the redeemed SOL.
Your BNSOL will be still entitled to staking rewards even when it is used in other Binance products or external DeFi applications.

Unclaimed Rewards is the trading fees you receive from the trading activity within the pool plus the additional rewards. This is distributed hourly.

The Flexible Trial Fund can be used to subscribe to Binance Simple Earn Flexible Products. The daily Bonus Tiered APR rewards generated by the subscribed Flexible Product with the trial fund will be distributed to your Spot Wallet.

You will receive Bonus Tiered APR Rewards for the duration of the Accruing Period. These rewards are accrued the day after subscription, starting at 00:00 UTC, and are distributed to your Spot Wallet the day after accrual starts (two days after subscription) between 00:00 UTC and 08:00 UTC. The APR is subject to daily changes.
Real-Time APR rewards are not applicable to Flexible Trial Fund subscriptions.
"The trial fund is neither redeemable nor withdrawable or transferable. The principal of the Flexible Trial Fund, not being a part of the rewards, won't be redeemed once the trial period ends."

The Locked Trial Fund can be used to subscribe to Binance Simple Earn Locked Products. The daily APR rewards generated by the subscribed Locked Product with the trial fund will be distributed to your Spot Wallet.

Daily APR Rewards will be distributed for the duration of the Accruing Period. These rewards are accrued the day after subscription, starting at 00:00 UTC, and are distributed to your Spot Wallet the day after accrual starts (two days after subscription) between 00:00 UTC and 08:00 UTC.
The Locked Product subscribed with the trial fund cannot be early redeemed. The principal will be redeemed to your Spot Wallet on the Redemption Date.

Turning Auto-Subscribe on means your corresponding assets (including interests and new token purchases) in Spot Wallet will be transferred to Earn Wallet every 24 hours. You can find the Auto-Subscribe history under Wallets > Earn History > Flexible.

By Wrapping BETH into WBETH, you will receive staking rewards in a different way. BETH rewards will not be distributed to your Spot Wallet directly, but compounded daily to increase the value of your WBETH.
Wrap into WBETH to explore more use cases of your staked ETH and yield opportunities
Wrap your %1$s BETH into WBETH and utilize them for a variety of use cases.

Wrapped Beacon ETH (WBETH) represents your staked Ethereum (ETH) and the staking reward received, in a tradable and transferable form. WBETH accumulates ETH staking rewards by growing in value in relation to ETH, even when it is used in Binance products or DeFi projects.

I understand the risks associated with using WBETH, that conversion ratio between ETH and WBETH is subject to change on a daily basis, and that if I redeem my WBETH back to ETH, I will receive the amount equal to the holdings of WBETH multiplied by the WBETH:ETH conversion ratio at the time of the swap.

I understand that there are limitations regarding the total WBETH that can be redeemed due to the design of ETH Staking on the Ethereum mainnet. Consequently, it is possible that I am not able to redeem WBETH to ETH at any time I want, and I may have to wait for the next time when the quota is open for redemption.

"Before you start trading, let's refresh your knowledge and make sure you understand how to avoid risk."
Isolated margin positions are not supported under the Multi-Assets Mode. Please adjust all USDⓈ-M Futures positions to cross margin mode in order to activate Multi-Assets Mode.

Activation Price is one of the trigger conditions for Trailing Stop order. If no activation price is set, the activation price will be the market price by default (either \"Last Price\" or \"Mark Price\"). When the highest/lowest market price reaches or exceeds the Activation Price after the Trailing Stop order is submitted, the condition is considered to be satisfied.
This indicator shows your position in the auto-deleverage queue. If all lights are lit, in the event of a liquidation, your position may be reduced.
The post only order will be auto-cancelled while adjusting a price to be filled immediately.
Strategy order does not support adjustment.
Adjustment confirmations will be required every time an order is submitted if this function is enabled.
Please note that the liquidation prices of your %1$s positions may change if you are using cross margin mode.

Callback Rate is one of the trigger conditions for Trailing Stop order. After the Activation Price is satisfied, if the rebound rate of the highest/lowest market price is greater than or equal to the Callback Rate, the Trailing Stop Order will be executed. The callback rate ranges from 0.1% to 5%.

"The proportion of net long and net short accounts to total accounts of the top 20% users with the highest margin balance. Each account is counted once only.
<hl1>Long Account %</hl1> = Accounts of top traders with net long positions / Total accounts of top traders with open positions
<hl2>Short Account %</hl2> = Accounts of top traders with net short positions / Total accounts of top traders with open positions
<hl3>Long/Short Ratio (Accounts)</hl3> = Long Account % / Short Account %"

"The difference between the futures price and the price index at a given time.
<hl1>Basis</hl1> = Futures Price - Price Index
<hl2>Basis Rate</hl2> = ( Futures Price - Price Index ) / Price Index"

"The proportion of net long and net short positions to total open positions of the top 20% users with the highest margin balance.
<hl1>Long Position %</hl1> = Long positions of top traders / Total open positions of top traders
<hl2>Short Position %</hl2> = Short positions of top traders / Total open positions of top traders
<hl3>Long/Short Ratio (Positions)</hl3> = Long Position % / Short Position %"

"<hl1>Taker Buy Volume</hl1> The total volume of buy orders filled by takers within the period.
<hl2>Taker Sell Volume</hl2> The total volume of sell orders filled by takers within the period."

"The proportion of net long and net short accounts to total accounts with positions. Each account is counted once only.
<hl1>Long Account %</hl1> = Accounts with net long positions / Total Accounts with positions
<hl2>Short Account %</hl2> = Accounts with net short positions / Total Accounts with positions
<hl3>Long/Short Ratio</hl3> = Long Account % / Short Account %"

Estimated liquidation price is only a predicted value when a position is first initiated. The actual liquidation price will depend on the trading price, open orders and commission fees, which may vary from the estimated liquidation price. Please note that this calculation is for reference only.

Trailing Stop orders allow traders to send a pre-set order to the market when a market swing takes place. When the latest Market Price/Mark Price reaches the highest/lowest price (1 ± Callback Rate) after an order is submitted, this triggers the order to be executed on the market and the Trigger Price will be the highest/lowest price* (1 ± Callback Rate).

30 Days Cumulative Funding Rate is the Sum of the funding rate settled in the recent 720 hours.
3 Days Cumulative Funding Rate is the Sum of the funding rate settled in the recent 72 hours.
%1$s = ( |3 Day Cum. Funding Rate%%| - 3 Day Interest%%)* Position Size (USDT) / 2
Buy and Sell trading pair for funding rate arbitrage based on historical 3 Day Cumulative Funding Rate.
7 Days Cumulative Funding Rate is the Sum of the funding rate settled in the recent 168 hours.
APR = | Average (%1$d Days Funding Rate%% / Funding Interval) | * 24 * 365
APR = | Average (%1$d Days Funding Rate%% / Funding Interval) | * 24 * 365
%1$s = ( | N Day Cum. Rate%%| - N Day Interest%%) / N * 365
APR = | Next Funding Rate | / Funding Interval * 24 * 365

In COIN-M futures, the total paid funding fee is the notional value of all coins paid as funding fee in the selected time interval.
In COIN-M futures, the total received funding fee is the notional value of all coins received as funding fee in the selected time interval.
In COIN-M futures, the total funding fee is the notional value of all coins received or paid as funding fees in the selected time interval.
In COIN-M futures, the total transaction fee is the notional value of all coins paid as transaction fees in the selected time interval.
The payment rate exchanged between the long and short positions for the next funding. If the funding rate is positive, longs pay shorts. If negative, shorts pay longs.

"When the Current Price (A) drops to the order’s Limit Price (C) or below, the order will execute automatically. The order will be filled immediately if the buying price is above or equal to the current price. Therefore, the buying price of limit orders must be below the current price.
For example: 1) The current price in the above graph is 2400 (A). If a new buy/limit order is placed with Limit price 1500 (C), the order will not execute until the price drops to %@.
2) Instead, if the buy/limit order is placed with Limit price %@, which is above the current price, the order will be filled with the rival price immediately. And the executed price is around 2400, not 3000."

When the Current Price (A) drops to the order’s Limit Price (C) or below, the order will execute automatically. The order will be filled immediately if the buying price is above or equal to the current price. Therefore, the buying price of limit orders must be below the current price.

"For example: 1) The current price in the above graph is 2400 (A). If a new buy/limit order is placed with a limit price of 1500 (C), the order will not execute until the price drops to %@.
2) Instead, if the buy/limit order is placed with a limit price of %@, which is above the current price, the order will be filled with the counterparty price immediately. The executed price is around 2400, not 3000."

"For example: 1) The current price in the above graph is 2,400 (A). If a new buy/limit order is placed with a limit price of 1,500 (C), the order will not execute until the price drops to %@.
2) Instead, if the buy/limit order is placed with a limit price of %@, which is above the current price, the order will be filled at the counterparty price immediately. The executed price is around 2,400, not 3,000."
A Limit order is an order to buy or sell at a specific price or better. Limit orders are not guaranteed to execute.

"When the Current Price (A) increases to the order’s Limit Price (B) or above, the order will execute automatically. The order might be filled immediately if the selling price is below or equal to the current price. Therefore, the selling price of limit orders must be above the current price.
For example: 1) The current price in the above graph is 2400 (A), if a new sell/limit order is placed with Limit Price 3000 (B), the order will not execute until the price increases to %@.
2) Instead, if the sell/limit order is placed with Limit Price %@, which is below the current price, the order would be filled with the rival price immediately; the filled price is around 2400, not 1500."

When the Current Price (A) increases to the order’s Limit Price (B) or above, the order will execute automatically. The order might be filled immediately if the selling price is below or equal to the current price. Therefore, the selling price of limit orders must be above the current price.

"For example: 1) The current price in the above graph is 2400 (A), if a new sell/limit order is placed with a limit price of 3000 (B), the order will not execute until the price increases to %@.
2) Instead, if the sell/limit order is placed with a limit price of %@, which is below the current price, the order would be filled with the counterparty price immediately. The filled price is around 2400, not 1500."

"For example: 1) The current price in the above graph is 2,400 (A). If a new sell/limit order is placed with a limit price of 3,000 (B), the order will not execute until the price increases to %@.
2) Instead, if the sell/limit order is placed with a limit price of %@, which is below the current price, the order would be filled at the counterparty price immediately. The filled price is around 2,400, not 1,500."

"The current price is 2400. If you place a market order, your order will be filled with %@ immediately, it means the average filled price won’t be equal to 2400(A), which is supposed to be a bit lower or higher than 2400.
Note: For buy orders, the average filled price might be a bit higher than current price. And for sell orders, the average filled price might be a bit lower than current price."

"The current price is 2,400. If you place a market order, your order will be filled with %@ immediately. This means the average filled price won’t be equal to 2,400(A), which is supposed to be a bit lower or higher than 2,400.
Note: For buy orders, the average filled price might be a bit higher than the current price. For sell orders, the average filled price might be a bit lower than current price."

The current price is 2400 (A). At this point, place a Post Only Order . If the buy price (B) of order is %@ the current price, the buy order may be executed immediately, the order will be cancelled. Therefore, when a buy is required, the price (C) should be %@ the current price.

The current price is 2,400 (A). At this point, place a Post Only Order. If the buy price (B) of the order is %@ the current price, the buy order may be executed immediately, the order will be cancelled. Therefore, when a buy is required, the price (C) should be %@ the current price.
Post Only orders will be added to the order book and not execute with a pre-existing order

The current price is 2400 (A). At this point, place a Post Only Order . If the sell price (B) of order is %@ the current price, the sell order may be executed immediately, the order will be cancelled. Therefore, when a sell is required, the price (C) should be %@ the current price.

The current price is 2,400 (A). At this point, place a Post Only Order. If the sell price (B) of the order is %@ the current price, the sell order may be executed immediately, the order will be cancelled. Therefore, when a sell is required, the price (C) should be %@ the current price.

"Ascending: The order size systematically grows as the price escalates. The last order is characterised by the highest price and largest quantity, resulting in more of the asset being traded at a higher price. It's commonly employed to distribute sell orders and elevate the average selling price of the order."

A scaled order automatically generates multiple limit orders within a specified price range. It splits the order amount into several suborders and places them separately without significantly impacting the market.

"Descending: The order size systematically grows as the price decrease. The last order is characterised with the lowest price and largest quantity resulting in more of the asset being traded at a lower price. It's commonly employed to distribute buy order and reduce the average buying price of the order."

Flat: This type of distribution is the most straightforward. Each order within your total amount receives the same size. The amount distribution is uniform across all price points. You can use [Flat] when you expect the price to fluctuate within the range but have no specific bias towards it moving upwards or downwards.

"Random: As suggested by its name, this distribution type randomly allocates the size of each order at every price point within a defined range. With a random distribution, you'll need to enter the variance % (up to 10%). If you opt for a variance of 10%, it means the order sizes will be randomly distributed across a range with a 10% variation."

Stop Limit Orders execute when a specified price is reached. Specify a trigger price to activate the order. It can be used to set a Stop loss Limit or Take Profit Limit Order. Please note, the system will automatically reject orders that fail margin check or exceed position limit.

"The current price is 2400 (A). The stop price of the stop limit order can be above the current price such as 3000 (B), or below the current price such as 1500 (C). Once the price goes up to 3000 (B) or drops down to 1500 (C), the stop limit order triggers, and the limit order will be activated automatically.
Note: 1) Limit price can be above or below stop price for both buy and sell orders. For example, %@ is able to combine with a lower %@, or a higher %@.
2) Limit order is invalid before the stop price is triggered, including when the limit price is reached ahead of the stop price.
3) When the stop price is reached, it only indicates that a limit order is activated and will be submitted to the market, rather than the limit order being filled immediately. The limit order will execute with its own rules.
4)The Stop Price can be the Mark Price or the Last Price."

"The current price is 2,400 (A). The stop price of the stop limit order can be above the current price such as 3,000 (B), or below the current price such as 1,500 (C). Once the price goes up to 3,000 (B) or drops down to 1,500 (C), the stop limit order triggers, and the limit order will be activated automatically.
Note: 1) Limit price can be above or below stop price for both buy and sell orders. For example, %@ is able to combine with a lower %@, or a higher %@.
2) Limit order is invalid before the stop price is triggered, including when the limit price is reached ahead of the stop price.
3) When the stop price is reached, it only indicates that a limit order is activated and will be submitted to the market, rather than the limit order being filled immediately. The limit order will execute with its own rules.
4) The Stop Price can be the Mark Price or the Last Price."

Stop Market Orders execute when a specified price is reached. Specify a trigger price to activate the order. It can be used to set a Stop loss Market or Take Profit Market Order. Please note, the system will automatically reject orders that fail margin check or exceed position limit.

"The current price is 2400 (A). The Stop Price of the Stop Market Order can be above the current price such as 3000 (B), or below the current price such as 1500 (C). Once the price goes up to 3000 (B) or drops down to 1500 (C), the Stop Market Order triggers, and the Market Order will be activated automatically.
Note: The Stop Price can be the Mark Price or the Last Price."

"The current price is 2,400 (A). The Stop Price of the Stop Market Order can be above the current price such as 3,000 (B), or below the current price such as 1,500 (C). Once the price goes up to 3,000 (B) or drops down to 1,500 (C), the Stop Market Order triggers, and the Market Order will be activated automatically.
Note: The Stop Price can be the Mark Price or the Last Price."

"The current price is 2400 (A). At this point, place a Trailing Stop Order. For buy, the activation price (B) needs to be lower than the current price (A). If the lowest market price has reached or exceeded the activation price (B), and then rebound rate is greater than or equal to the callback rate (C), this triggers the order to be executed as a market order.
For example: 1）The current price in the above graph is 2400 (A). A new buy trailing stop order is placed with activation price 1500 (B), callback rate 5% (C).
2）When the price rises, the buy trailing stop order will not take effect. Only when the price drops, and the lowest market price has reached or exceeded the activation price 1500 (B), one of the conditions of trailing stop order is satisfied.
3）Then rebound rate is greater than or equal to the callback rate 5% (C), which is C=Market Lowest Price*(1+5%), two conditions of trailing stop order are satisfied. This triggers the order to be executed as a market order."

"The current price is 2,400 (A). At this point, place a Trailing Stop Order. For buy, the activation price (B) needs to be lower than the current price (A). If the lowest market price has reached or exceeded the activation price (B), and then the rebound rate is greater than or equal to the callback rate (C), this triggers the order to be executed as a market order.
For example: 1)The current price in the above graph is 2,400 (A). A new buy trailing stop order is placed with activation price 1,500 (B), callback rate 5% (C).
2)When the price rises, the buy trailing stop order will not take effect. Only when the price drops, and the lowest market price has reached or exceeded the activation price 1,500 (B), one of the conditions of the trailing stop order is satisfied.
3)Then the rebound rate is greater than or equal to the callback rate 5% (C), which is C = Market Lowest Price * (1+5%), two conditions of the trailing stop order are satisfied. This triggers the order to be executed as a market order."

"Trailing Stop orders allow traders to send a pre-set order to the market when a market swing takes place. When the latest Market Price/Mark Price reaches the highest/lowest price (1 ± Callback Rate) after an order is submitted, this triggers the order to be executed as a market order.
Callback Rate is one of the trigger conditions for Trailing Stop order. After the Activation Price is satisfied, if the rebound rate of the highest/lowest market price is greater than or equal to the Callback Rate, the Trailing Stop Order will be executed. The callback rate ranges from 0.1% to 5%.
Activation Price is one of the trigger conditions for Trailing Stop order. If no activation price is set, the activation price will be the market price by default (either “Last Price” or “Mark Price”). When the highest/lowest market price reaches or exceeds the Activation Price after the Trailing Stop order is submitted, the condition is considered to be satisfied."

"The current price is 2400 (A). At this point, place a Trailing Stop Order. For sell, the activation price (B) needs to be higher than the current price (A). If the highest market price has reached or exceeded the activation price (B), and then rebound rate is greater than or equal to the callback rate (C), this triggers the order to be executed as a market order.
For example: 1）The current price in the above graph is 2400 (A). A new sell trailing stop order is placed with activation price 3000 (B), callback rate 5% (C).
2）When the price drops, the sell trailing stop order will not take effect. Only when the price rises, and the highest market price has reached or exceeded the activation price 3000 (B), one of the conditions of trailing stop order is satisfied.
3）Then rebound rate is greater than or equal to the callback rate 5% (C), which is C=Market Highest Price*(1-5%), two conditions of trailing stop order are satisfied. This triggers the order to be executed as a market order."

"The current price is 2,400 (A). At this point, place a Trailing Stop Order. For sell, the activation price (B) needs to be higher than the current price (A). If the highest market price has reached or exceeded the activation price (B), and then the rebound rate is greater than or equal to the callback rate (C), this triggers the order to be executed as a market order.
For example: 1)The current price in the above graph is 2,400 (A). A new sell trailing stop order is placed with activation price 3,000 (B), callback rate 5% (C).
2)When the price drops, the sell trailing stop order will not take effect. Only when the price rises, and the highest market price has reached or exceeded the activation price 3,000 (B), one of the conditions of the trailing stop order is satisfied.
3)Then rebound rate is greater than or equal to the callback rate 5% (C), which is C = Market Highest Price * (1-5%), two conditions of trailing stop order are satisfied. This triggers the order to be executed as a market order."

"Time-Weighted Average Price (TWAP) is the average price calculated over a period of time. TWAP trading algorithm aims to execute a trade over a user-specified period of time so that the average execution price is approximately in line with the time-weighted average price of that period.
The Total Size is the size of the contract you choose to buy or sell. The minimum total size of a TWAP order is equivalent to 10,000 USDT. When a TWAP Strategy completes all orders, the TWAP order will stop.
Total Time is the length of time to run the TWAP. The minimum time is 5 minutes, and maximum is 24 hours.
When is the best time to use TWAP? TWAP is favoured to provide a better execution price in the following scenarios: · Order size larger than available liquidity on the order book. · Anticipation of high price volatility period with no clear up or downward trend."

When the price rises above the midline and moves in the direction of the upper band, this may indicate that the market is on an upward trend.
If the price continues to rise and reaches or breaks through the upper band, we call this \"overbought\".
At this point, there will be pressure to sell as people seek to exit the markets with their profits. The upward momentum falters and the price may drop back to the midline.
If the price falls below the midline and continues in the direction of the lower band, this indicates a downtrend.

If the price continues to decrease and and hits or falls below the lower band, we call this oversold. At this point, a supporting force will appear as people interested to buy low may choose to enter the market. The price will be affected by such momentum and may start to move back to the midline.
It is of course possible for the price to break through the upper band and then continue to soar, or fall below the lower band and then continue to fall.

The Bollinger Bands are better suited for short-term trading, and can be used in combination with other indicators to determine the trading point. We recommend using various indicators and data to avoid fake signals.

The Bollinger Band is composed of three lines, where the middle line represents SMA (Simple Moving Average). This is usually preset to 20 time periods, then a line is added above and below to indicate the upper and lower bands respectively.
"Middle line: 20-day SMA Upper band: 20-day SMA + (20-day standard deviation x2) Lower band: 20-day SMA - (20-day standard deviation x2)"

The wider the width distance is between the upper and lower bands, the larger the standard deviation and the greater the volatility. Conversely, a narrower distance indicates that the market is relatively less volatile. Most K-lines will fall within the Bollinger Band.

In contrast, a bearish crossover (or Death Cross) happens when a short-term MA crosses below a long-term one, which indicates the beginning of a downtrend.
A bullish crossover (also known as a Golden Cross) happens when the short-term MA crosses above a long-term one, suggesting the start of an upward trend.

"Take a look at the relationship between the K-line and the MA. If the recent prices were below the MA but today's K-line is higher than the MA, it can be interpreted that the current price has already moved above the average price. This can mean that the market is strengthening."
The yellow line indicates the average price of the last 7 days. The purple line indicates the average price of the last 25 days.
Therefore, in this chart, SMA (25) represents the long-term trend and SMA (7) shows the short-term trend.
Always remember that indicators are neutral. Relying on any one of them alone would not ensure trading wins all the time.
Thus, we encourage you to reference different indicators in combination with other factors to avoid fake signals.

Another popular indicator is the Exponential Moving Average (EMA), which is based on MA. The EMA puts more weight on the more current data. This means that the closer the price is to the present, the more important it becomes. On the other hand, the farther away it is, the less important it becomes.
The recent price is given a higher weightage and a less recent price, a lower weightage. The weightage exponentially decreases from the most recent to the least recent prices.
This design makes the EMA much more sensitive than the MA, and can quickly reflect the recent price trend changes in the market.
MA stands for Moving Average (sometimes also known as Simple Moving Average or SMA). It refers to the average closing price from the previous period.

"The current price is %1$s (A). The stop price of the stop limit order can be above the current price such as %2$s (B), or below the current price such as %3$s (C). Once the price goes up to %4$s (B) or drops down to %5$s (C), the stop limit order triggers, and the limit order will be activated automatically.
Note: 1) Limit price can be above or below stop price for both buy and sell orders. For example, "stop price B is able to combine with a lower limit price B1, or a higher limit price B2".
2) Limit order is invalid before the stop price is triggered, including when the limit price is reached ahead of the stop price.
3) When the stop price is reached, it only indicates that a limit order is activated and will be submitted to the market, rather than the limit order being filled immediately. The limit order will execute with its own rules.
4) The Stop Price can be the Mark Price or the Last Price."

"The current price is %1$s (A). The Stop Price of the Stop Market Order can be above the current price such as %2$s (B), or below the current price such as %3$s (C). Once the price goes up to %4$s (B) or drops down to %5$s (C), the Stop Market Order triggers, and the Market Order will be activated automatically.
Note: The Stop Price can be the Mark Price or the Last Price."

"When the Current Price (A) drops to the order’s Limit Price (C) or below, the order will execute automatically. The order will be filled immediately if the buying price is above or equal to the current price. Therefore, the buying price of limit orders must be below the current price.
For example: 1) The current price in the above graph is %1$s (A). If a new buy/limit order is placed with a limit price of %2$s (C), the order will not execute until the price drops to "%3$s(C) or below".
2) Instead, if the buy/limit order is placed with a limit price of "%4$s(B), which is above the current price, the order will be filled at the counterparty price immediately. The executed price is around %5$s, not %6$s.

"When the Current Price (A) increases to the order’s Limit Price (B) or above, the order will execute automatically. The order might be filled immediately if the selling price is below or equal to the current price. Therefore, the selling price of limit orders must be above the current price.
For example: 1) The current price in the above graph is %1$s (A). If a new sell/limit order is placed with a limit price of %2$s (B), the order will not execute until the price increases to "%3$s (B) or above".
2) Instead, if the sell/limit order is placed with a limit price of "%4$s (C), which is below the current price, the order would be filled at the counterparty price immediately. The filled price is around %5$s, not %6$s.

The current price is %1$s. If you place a market order, your order will be filled with rival price" immediately, it means the average filled price won’t be equal to %2$s(A), which is supposed to be a bit lower or higher than %3$s.
Note: For buy orders, the average filled price might be a bit higher than current price. For sell orders, the average filled price might be a bit lower than current price."

The current price is %1$s (A). At this point, place a Post Only Order. If the buy price (B) of the order is higher than or equal to the current price, the buy order may be executed immediately, and the order will be cancelled. Therefore, when a buy is required, the price (C) should be lower than the current price.

The current price is %1$s (A). At this point, place a Post Only Order. If the sell price (B) of the order is lower than or equal to the current price, the sell order may be executed immediately, and the order will be cancelled. Therefore, when a sell is required, the price (C) should be higher than the current price.

"The current price is %1$s (A). The stop price of the stop limit order can be above the current price such as %2$s (B), or below the current price such as %3$s (C). Once the price goes up to %4$s (B) or drops down to %5$s (C), the stop limit order triggers, and the limit order will be activated automatically.
Note: 1) Limit price can be above or below stop price for both buy and sell orders. For example, "stop price B is able to combine with a lower limit price B1, or a higher limit price B2".
2) Limit order is invalid before the stop price is triggered, including when the limit price is reached ahead of the stop price.
3) When the stop price is reached, it only indicates that a limit order is activated and will be submitted to the market, rather than the limit order being filled immediately. The limit order will execute with its own rules.
4) The Stop Price can be the Mark Price or the Last Price."

"The current price is %1$s (A). The Stop Price of the Stop Market Order can be above the current price such as %2$s (B), or below the current price such as %3$s (C). Once the price goes up to %4$s (B) or drops down to %5$s (C), the Stop Market Order triggers, and the Market Order will be activated automatically.
Note: The Stop Price can be the Mark Price or the Last Price."

"The current price is %1$s (A). At this point, place a Trailing Stop Order. For buy, the activation price (B) needs to be lower than the current price (A). If the lowest market price has reached or exceeded the activation price (B), and then rebound rate is greater than or equal to the callback rate (C), this triggers the order to be executed as a market order.
For example: 1)The current price in the above graph is %2$s (A). A new buy trailing stop order is placed with activation price %3$s (B), callback rate 5%% (C).
2)When the price rises, the buy trailing stop order will not take effect. Only when the price drops, and the lowest market price has reached or exceeded the activation price %4$s (B), one of the conditions of trailing stop order is satisfied.
3)Then rebound rate is greater than or equal to the callback rate 5%% (C), which is C=Market Lowest Price*(1+5%%), two conditions of trailing stop order are satisfied. This triggers the order to be executed as a market order."

"The current price is %1$s (A). At this point, place a Trailing Stop Order. For sell, the activation price (B) needs to be higher than the current price (A). If the highest market price has reached or exceeded the activation price (B), and then rebound rate is greater than or equal to the callback rate (C), this triggers the order to be executed as a market order.
For example: 1)The current price in the above graph is %2$s (A). A new sell trailing stop order is placed with activation price %3$s (B), callback rate 5%% (C).
2)When the price drops, the sell trailing stop order will not take effect. Only when the price rises, and the highest market price has reached or exceeded the activation price %4$s (B), one of the conditions of trailing stop order is satisfied.
3)Then rebound rate is greater than or equal to the callback rate 5%% (C), which is C=Market Highest Price*(1-5%%), two conditions of trailing stop order are satisfied. This triggers the order to be executed as a market order."

"With the 'Order Execution' notifications feature enabled, you will instantly be notified on your page each time an order is executed by a user you're following. You have the option to customize notifications for each user you follow by either enabling or disabling them, with the settings taking effect immediately."

With \"Followers/Following List\" sharing disabled, other users are unable to view your \"Followers/Following List\". If you reactivate this feature, your \"Followers/Following List\" will become immediately accessible to other users.

When you turn on \"Performance\" sharing, your ROI, PnL, and Weekly Ranking get public exposure on your profile page, and you may appear on high visibility rankings like the \"Top Traders\" list or product-specific lists. Disabling it, on the other hand, immediately hides these metrics and removes your presence from all rankings, potentially causing a drop in the visibility of your profile.

"With \"Performance\" sharing disabled, other users can't view your statistics right away. However, if you reactivate it, your data becomes immediately accessible, with a 24-hour waiting period for inclusion in the ranking list."

Enabling \"Current Positions\" sharing displays your \"Current Positions\" and \"Last Trade\" date on your profile page for public view. Disabling it will instantly hide both your \"Current Positions\" and \"Last Trade\" date. Changes to your profile page take effect immediately.

When you enable Data Overview sharing, your PNL and ROI appear on your Profile Page or the Top Ranking leaderboard. Turning off this feature not only keeps your PNL and ROI private, but also prevents you from viewing them in your Data Overview. Disabling takes about a minute, while enabling again can take up to 24 hours. USDⓈ-M and COIN-M share the same settings.

Choosing to share your positions publicly makes them visible to other users on your Profile Page. For privacy, disabling this feature will make your positions invisible to others. Changes take effect immediately when you toggle this option. You can set different sharing statuses for USDⓈ-M and COIN-M, respectively.
*Ranking of the sharing poster is displayed according to the ranking of your shared positions/unshared positions

Collateral Margin Level (CML) of Cross Margin Account = Collateral Value / (Total Liabilities + Outstanding Interest)

Collateral Margin Level affects the maximum transferred out amount. You may transfer collateral out of your account, up to the point where the remaining collateral value (after haircuts) deducted by the sum of all open order losses is more than twice the amount of the total liabilities plus interest. The maximum transfer out amount is further reduced by assets locked in pending orders.

Trading costs (i.e. commissions, funding and liquidation fees) are deducted from the P&L calculation. Account level P&L analysis includes transactional P&L and fees, and unrealized exchange rate P&L from holding assets, all valued on USD basis. Due to data complexity and exchange rate fluctuation, there may be a margin of error or delay. All data is for reference only. We are sorry for any inconvenience caused.
PNL ratio = Cumulative PNL / (asset in your Margin account from day 1 + average net transfer from day 1 to day N)

The difference between the Futures price and the price index at a given time. Basis = Futures Price - Price. Index Basis Rate = ( Futures Price - Price Index ) / Price Index. Only available for 5m, 15m, 30m, 1h, 2h, 4h, 6h, 12h, and 1d time intervals.

Taker Buy Volume: the total volume of buy orders filled by takers within a given period. Taker Sell Volume: the total volume of sell orders filled by takers within a given period. Only available for 5m, 15m, 30m, 1h, 2h, 4h, 6h, 12h, and 1d time intervals.
Not supported on Mark/Index Price. Please switch to Last Price

The proportion of net long and net short accounts to total accounts of the top 20% users with the highest margin balance. Each account is counted only once. Long Account% = Accounts of top traders with net long positions / Total accounts of top traders with open positions. Short Account% = Accounts of top traders with net short positions / Total accounts of top traders with open positions. Long/Short Ratio (Accounts) = Long Account% / Short Account%. Only available for 5m, 15m, 30m, 1h, 2h, 4h, 6h, 12h, and 1d time intervals.

The proportion of net long and net short positions to total open positions of the top 20% of users with the highest margin balance. Long Position% = Long positions of top traders / Total open positions of top traders. Short Position% = Short positions of top traders / Total open positions of top traders. Long/Short Ratio (Positions) = Long Position% / Short Position%. Only available for 5m, 15m, 30m, 1h, 2h, 4h, 6h, 12h, and 1d time intervals.

The proportion of net long and net short accounts to total accounts with positions. Each account is counted only once. Long Account% = Accounts with net long positions / Total Accounts with positions. Short Account% = Accounts with net short positions / Total Accounts with positions. Long/Short Ratio = Long Account% / Short Account%. Only available for 5m, 15m, 30m, 1h, 2h, 4h, 6h, 12h, and 1d time intervals.
Notional Value of Open Interest. Only available for 5m, 15m, 30m, 1h, 2h, 4h, 6h, 12h, and 1d time intervals.

BNB is a token issued by Binance, with a constant total supply of 200 million. It can be used to enjoy discounts and fee deductions.

BTC is the representative currency of digital assets and the most famous digital currency. The biggest difference between it and other digital currencies is that the total quantity is very limited and it is extremely scarce.

BUSD is a stable currency that is anchored 1:1 with the US Dollar based on blockchain technology. It uses an independent third-party accounting firm to audit assets that can be used as a hedge currency.
USDT is a digital currency pegged to the US Dollar. The exchange ratio is 1:1 and it is used as a currency to replact the US Dollar in cryptocurrency exchanges.

"A Binance Option is a type of European Option contract which, unlike American-style Options, can only be exercised at expiry, but can be bought or sold at the current market price at any time prior to expiry.
Options trading is a highly risky endeavor with the potential for both great profits and significant losses.
The maximum loss of an Options buyer is the amount of premium paid to purchase the Option. An Options seller may, however, lose the entire amount of margin posted to collateralize their position and risks being subject to liquidation if sufficient margin is not maintained.
Options trading is restricted for users from certain regions. Only certain users will be eligible to act as Option Sellers.
By trading Options on Binance, you will be subject to the terms of the Binance Options Service Agreement."

"When the current price (A) drops to the order's limit price (C) or below, the order will execute automatically. The order will be filled immediately if the buying price is above or equal to the current price. Therefore, the buying price of limit orders should be below the current price. For example: 1) The current price in the above graph is %1$s (A). If a new buy limit order is placed with a limit price of %2$s (C), the order will not execute until the price drops to "%3$s (C) or below".
2) However, if the buy/limit order is placed with a limit price of "%4$s (B), which is above the current price, the order will be filled with the counterparty price immediately. The executed price will be around %5$s, not %6$s.

"When the current price (A) increases to the order's limit price (B) or above, the order will execute automatically. The order will be filled immediately if the selling price is below or equal to the current price. Therefore, the selling price of limit orders should be above the current price. For example: 1) The current price in the above graph is %1$s (A). If a new sell/limit order is placed with a limit price of %2$s (B), the order will not execute until the price increases to "%3$s (B) or above".
2) However, if the sell/limit order is placed with a limit price "%4$s (C), which is below the current price, the order would be filled with the counterparty price immediately. The filled price will be around %5$s, not %6$s.

"\"UniMMR=Adjusted Equity/Maintainance Margin. UniMMR is the ratio we use toe control the position's risk.
1.2 < UniMMR <=1.5, you should add additional funds to avoid liquidation.
UniMMR <=1.2, trade restricted. Unable to trade or withdraw, and can only place reduce only orders.
UniMMR <= 1.05, liquidation triggered.
The info here only considers data of this order and is only for reference as uniMMR will change constantly.\""

Your Portfolio Margin account will undergo the liquidation process. All pending orders in Cross Margin and Futures will be canceled, and all Futures positions will be closed. Outstanding debts in Cross Margin and Futures will be settled, and any remaining assets will be converted to the settle-in-crypto you choose.

Amounts received may differ due to the nature of market orders. Large positions may require longer processing times and may experience larger slippage. You will not be able to operate on your Portfolio Margin account before the Close All operation is finished.

Your Portfolio Margin account will undergo the liquidation process, during which no liquidation fees will be charged. "Total USD value of all the borrowed assets in Margin Account and negative balances in UM and CM account, including unrepaid interest. When the negative balances exceed the threshold of the asset, you need to repay interest. You will enter the \"auto exchange\" procedure if your negative balance exceeds the maximum allowed (see <hl1>threshold data</hl1>). Interest-bearing debt includes borrowed assets in Margin Account and negative balances in UM and CM Account that exceed the threshold, while interest-free debt is the negative balance below the threshold.
Interest-bearing debts: %1$s USD Interest-free debts: %2$s USD Total unpaid interest: %3$s USD"

"The Trigger Price (B) for Stop Limit (or Stop Market) should be higher than the Current Price(A) for buy order, and the Limit Price (C) for Limit Order should be lower than the Current Price(A).
Note: 1) The Stop Limit order is intended to be triggered when the market price rises to <hl1>3000 (B)</hl1>, at which point the Limit order will be canceled. <hl2>View Stop Limit Order</hl2>
2) If the user prefers a Stop Market order, it will be filled immediately when the market price rises to <hl3>3000 (B)</hl3>, and the Limit order will be canceled at the same time. <hl4>View Stop Market Order</hl4>
3) Conversely, if the price drops to <hl5>1500 (C) or below</hl5>, the Limit order will execute automatically, and the Stop Limit (or Stop Market) order will be canceled at the same time. <hl6>View Limit Order</hl6>"

"The Stop Price (B) should be higher than the market price for buy orders, and the Limit Price (C) should be lower than the market price.
Note: 1) The Stop Limit order is intended to be triggered when the market price rises to <hl1>3,000 (B)</hl1>, at which point the Limit order will be canceled. <hl2>View Stop Limit Order</hl2>
2) If the user prefers a Stop Market order, it will be filled immediately when the market price rises to <hl3>3,000 (B)</hl3>, and the Limit order will be canceled at the same time. <hl4>View Stop Market Order</hl4>
3) Conversely, if the price drops to <hl5>1,500 (C) or below</hl5>, the Limit order will execute automatically, and the Stop Limit (or Stop Market) order will be canceled at the same time. <hl6>View Limit Order</hl6>"

"The Trigger Price (C) for Stop Limit (or Stop Market) should be lower than the Current Price(A) for sell order, and the Limit Price (B) for Limit Order should be higher than the Current Price(A).
Note: 1) The Stop Limit order is intended to be triggered when the market price drops to <hl1>1500 (C)</hl1>, at which point the Limit order will be canceled. <hl2>View Stop Limit Order</hl2>
2) If the user prefers a Stop Market order, it will be filled immediately when the market price drops to <hl3>1500 (C)</hl3>, and the Limit order will be canceled at the same time. <hl4>View Stop Market Order</hl4>
3) Conversely, if the price rises to <hl5>3000 (B) or above</hl5>, the Limit order will execute automatically, and the Stop Limit (or Stop Market) order will be canceled at the same time. <hl6>View Limit Order</hl6>"

"The Stop Price (C) should be lower than the market price for sell orders, and the Limit Price (B) should be higher than the market price.
Note: 1) The Stop Limit order is intended to be triggered when the market price drops to <hl1>1,500 (C)</hl1>, at which point the Limit order will be canceled. <hl2>View Stop Limit Order</hl2>
2) If the user prefers a Stop Market order, it will be filled immediately when the market price drops to <hl3>1,500 (C)</hl3>, and the Limit order will be canceled at the same time. <hl4>View Stop Market Order</hl4>

"Binance Leveraged Tokens Risk Disclosure Statement Please read this risk disclosure statement carefully. Binance describes the general and specific risks associated with Leveraged Tokens (“Leveraged Tokens”) as part of Binance’s products and services you may enter into from time to time. This statement is not meant to be an exhaustive list. You must read this statement in accordance with Binance Terms of Use found at https://www.binance.com/en/terms. Binance offers Leveraged Tokens as products and services to you on the basis that you understand the risks involved.  You should always carefully consider whether Binance Leveraged Tokens are consistent with your risk tolerance, investment objectives, investment experience or sophistication, financial condition, financial needs and personal circumstances, and other considerations that may be relevant to you. You should keep yourself informed and be aware of investment risks generally, and in particular, the following: Binance Leveraged Tokens are an investment with risk. Investing/trading in Leveraged Tokens is a risky endeavour. Although Binance Leveraged Tokens generally have lower risks and costs compared to derivatives and conventional leveraged tokens (managed by other than Binance), they are not a risk-free investment. As a trader, you acknowledge and agree that you shall access and use Binance Leveraged Tokens at your own risk. You should fully understand the risks associated with Binance Leveraged Tokens and be solely responsible and liable for any and all trading and non-trading activity on your Binance account. Do not enter into a transaction or invest using funds that are beyond your financial means. Binance Leveraged Tokens are not a long term investment. Investors or traders with longer-term investment horizons shall purchase and hold the Binance Leveraged Tokens at their own risk. There is a possibility that the value of Binance Leveraged Tokens can become zero (0) and cannot be recovered due to inherent market risks, high fees, slippage, rebalance algorithm frontrunning and any other perceived unknown risks associated with Binance Leveraged Tokens. Binance Leveraged Tokens rebalance on an as-needed basis only. Binance Leveraged Tokens are designed to be unpredictable in rebalance to reduce the vulnerability of being attacked by algorithms on market. Unlike conventional leveraged tokens (not managed by Binance), Binance Leveraged Tokens do not maintain a constant leverage ratio. Hence, Binance Leveraged Tokens only rebalance during extreme market movements. The rebalancing of positions of Binance Leveraged Tokens is governed by Binance’s proprietary algorithms with the aim to maximize correlation between Binance Leveraged Tokens and the underlying margin-leverage position without a profit-guarantee. Commissions, fees and charges associated with Binance Leveraged Tokens. Before you invest or trade Binance Leveraged Tokens, you should obtain a clear explanation of all commissions, fees and other charges for which you will be liable. These fees will affect your expected returns. i. Trading Fees: Trading fees are charged when buying or selling tokens in the Spot market, and the fee schedule is identical to Spot trading as further described in Section 7(c) of the Binance Terms of Use;  ii. Redemption Fees: Redemption fees are charged when users choose to redeem tokens, which is currently set at 0.1% per redemption;  iii. Management Fees: A daily management fee of 0.01% will be charged at 00:00 UTC and reflected directly in the net asset value of the Leveraged Tokens;  iv. Funding Fees: Funding fees are paid (or paid to) the underlying fund based on the funding rate and reflected directly in the net asset value of the Leveraged Tokens. Binance takes no fees for funding rate transfers; these are directly between traders. Binance reserves the right to modify or change the fees mentioned above at any time and at its sole discretion. Any such updated fees will apply prospectively to any trades or other transactions that take place following the effective date of such updated fees. You authorize Binance to remove any amounts from your account for any applicable fees owed by you under these Terms. Liquidity and pricing risks associated with Binance Leveraged Tokens. Due to the nature of Binance Leveraged Tokens’ centralized creation and market liquidity, Binance strives to provide adequate market liquidity and to make Binance Leveraged Tokens available at a fair price. Binance shall take reasonable steps, including, but not limited to, capital injection, additional tokens creation, and selling tokens in the secondary market to minimize the risks mentioned above. The daily total redemption limit of each Leveraged Token is capped at 100,000 tokens. Users may redeem each leveraged token up to the daily cap of 1,000 tokens per account, although this will generally be more expensive than selling them on the Spot market, and is not recommended during normal trading times."

Average Position Price = Total Position Cost / Current Position, if it is negative, it will not be calculated and displayed.
Position = Sum Buy Amount - Sum Sell Amount, if it is negative, it will not be calculated and displayed.
Latest Position Value = Current Position * Last Price, if current position is negative, it will not be calculated and displayed.
Only the buy and sell orders within the specified time range of the same symbol are counted, excluding deposit, withdraw, transfer and distribution. <hl1>FAQ</hl1>
Realized PNL = Sum Sell Amount * ( Average Sell Price - Average Buy Price) , if current position is negative, it will not be calculated and displayed.
Total Position Cost = Sum Buy Total - Sum Sell Total, if it is negative, it will not be calculated and displayed.
Unrealized PNL = Current Position * ( Last Price - Average Buy Price) , if current position is negative, it will not be calculated and displayed.

Iceberg order will split the original order into several orders, only after the current one is completed, the next one will be placed. The amount of the last iceberg will be the remainder of (Order Amount / Iceberg Amount). The number of icebergs (= the amount of the order/ iceberg amount) cannot be higher than 10 and must be lower than the total order amount. Iceberg orders follow regular trading rules, including the minimum order size, trading fee rates, etc.
