"For example: 1) The current price in the above graph is 2,400 (A). If a new buy/limit order is placed with a limit price of 1,500 (C), the order will not execute until the price drops to %1$@.
2) Instead, if the buy/limit order is placed with a limit price of %2$@, which is above the current price, the order will be filled with the counterparty price immediately. The executed price is around 2,400, not 3,000."

"For example: 1) The current price in the above graph is 2,400 (A), if a new sell/limit order is placed with a limit price of 3,000 (B), the order will not execute until the price increases to %1$@.
2) Instead, if the sell/limit order is placed with a limit price of %2$@, which is below the current price, the order would be filled with the counterparty price immediately. The filled price is around 2,400, not 1,500."

"The current price is 2,400. If you place a market order, your order will be filled with %1$@ immediately, it means the average filled price won’t be equal to 2,400(A), which is supposed to be a bit lower or higher than 2,400.
Note: 1) For buy orders, the average filled price might be a bit higher than current price. And for sell orders, the average filled price might be a bit lower than current price.
2) When placing a market order, you can either select [Amount] or [Total] to buy or sell."

"The Stop Price (B) should be higher than the market price for buy orders, and the Limit Price (C) should be lower than the market price
Note: 1) The Stop Limit order is intended to be triggered when the market price rises to <hl1>3,000 (B)</hl1>, at which point the Limit order will be canceled. <hl2>View Stop Limit Order</hl2>
2) If the user prefers a Stop Market order, it will be filled immediately when the market price rises to <hl3>3,000 (B)</hl3>, and the Limit order will be canceled at the same time. <hl4>View Stop Market Order</hl4>
3) Conversely, if the price drops to <hl5>1,500 (C) or below</hl5>, the Limit order will execute automatically, and the Stop Limit (or Stop Market) order will be canceled at the same time. <hl6>View Limit Order</hl6>"

"The Stop Price (C) should be lower than the market price for sell orders, and the Limit Price (B) should be higher than the market price
Note: 1) The Stop Limit order is intended to be triggered when the market price drops to <hl1>1,500 (C)</hl1>, at which point the Limit order will be canceled. <hl2>View Stop Limit Order</hl2>
2) If the user prefers a Stop Market order, it will be filled immediately when the market price drops to <hl3>1,500 (C)</hl3>, and the Limit order will be canceled at the same time. <hl4>View Stop Market Order</hl4>
3) Conversely, if the price rises to <hl5>3,000 (B) or above</hl5>, the Limit order will execute automatically, and the Stop Limit (or Stop Market) order will be canceled at the same time. <hl6>View Limit Order</hl6>"

The current price is 2400 (A). The Stop Price of the Stop Market Order can be above the current price such as 3000 (B), or below the current price such as 1500 (C). Once the price goes up to 3000 (B) or drops down to 1500 (C), the Stop Market Order triggers, and the Market Order will be activated automatically.

The current price is 2,400 (A). The Stop Price of the Stop Market Order can be above the current price such as 3,000 (B), or below the current price such as 1,500 (C). Once the price goes up to 3,000 (B) or drops down to 1,500 (C), the Stop Market Order triggers, and the Market Order will be activated automatically.
Stop Market Orders execute when a specified price is reached. Specify a trigger price to activate the order. It can be used to set a Stop loss Market or Take Profit Market Order.

"The current price is 2,400 (A). The stop price of the stop limit order can be above the current price such as 3,000 (B), or below the current price such as 1,500 (C). Once the price goes up to 3,000 (B) or drops down to 1,500 (C), the stop limit order triggers, and the limit order will be activated automatically.
Note: 1) Limit price can be above or below stop price for both buy and sell orders. For example, %1$@ is able to combine with a lower %2$@, or a higher %3$@.
2) Limit order is invalid before the stop price is triggered, including when the limit price is reached ahead of the stop price.
3) When the stop price is reached, it only indicates that a limit order is activated and will be submitted to the market, rather than the limit order being filled immediately. The limit order will execute with its own rules. %4$@"

The current price is 2,400 (A). The Stop Price of the Stop Market Order can be above the current price such as 3,000 (B), or below the current price such as 1,500 (C). Once the price goes up to 3,000 (B) or drops down to 1,500 (C), the Stop Market Order triggers, and the Market Order will be activated automatically.

"The Activation Price (B) is optional. If set, it should be lower than the Current Price (A), when the Activation Price (B) is met and the rebound rate is greater than or equal to the trailing delta, a Limit (D) or Market order at price C will be submitted.
For example: 1) The current price in the above graph is 1,700 (A). A new buy Trailing Stop order is created with an Activation Price of 1,500 (B), a trailing delta of 10%, and a limit price of 1,450 (D). The limit price can be any value, here we use 1,450 as an example.
2）When the market price reaches the Activation Price of 1,500 (B), one condition of the trailing stop order is satisfied. The second condition is satisfied when the price drops to 1,400 (Lowest Market Price) and then starts to rise, the rebound rate is greater than or equal to the trailing delta of 10%, the price will reach price C = 1,400 * (1 + 10%) = 1,540. This triggers the submission of the Limit order at 1,600 (D) to the order book.
3) If no limit price of 1,450 (D) is set, a Market order will be preferred. Once the second condition is met, a market order will be submitted and will fill immediately at the market price."

"The Activation Price (B) is optional. If set, it should be higher than the Current Price (A), when the Activation Price (B) is met and the rebound rate is greater than or equal to the trailing delta, a Limit (D) or Market order at price C will be submitted.
For example: 1) The current price in the above graph is 2,000 (A). A new sell Trailing Stop order is created with an Activation Price of 3,000 (B), a trailing delta of 10%, and a limit price of 3,100 (D). The limit price can be any value, here we use 3,100 as an example.
2）When the market price reaches the Activation Price of 3,000 (B), one condition of the trailing stop order is satisfied. The second condition is satisfied when the price rises to 3,200 (Highest Market Price) and then starts to drop, the rebound rate is greater than or equal to the trailing delta of 10%, the price will reach price C = 3,200 * (1 - 10%) = 2,880. This triggers the submission of the Limit order at 3,100 (D) to the order book.
3) If no limit price of 3,100 (D) is set, a Market order will be preferred. Once the second condition is met, a market order will be submitted and will fill immediately at the market price."

These terms (“Trading Bots Terms”) apply to the use of any trading tools available through the Binance Platform which enable Users to place orders for the execution of spot and/or futures transactions by way of a pre-determined execution methodology (such trading tools “Trading Bots” (otherwise referred to within the Platform as “Strategy Trading Tools”)).

"Furthermore, User acknowledges that Binance employs multiple risk mitigation strategies, including manual and automated circuit breakers, as well as kill-switch controls. These features can activate in the event of regulatory restrictions, market disruption, and/or systems failure, potentially canceling any Grid Trading Strategy in place. Binance shall not be liable to User in respect of any losses incurred in connection with the cancellation of any Grid Trading Strategy.
"

"Given the associated risks, Users shall be responsible for ensuring that they fully understand the risks of any Grid Trading Strategy and for conducting thorough due diligence to ensure that this feature is suitable for them.
Transactions entered into via a Grid Trading Strategy may incur trading fees. User should consider the impact of trading fees on the performance of the relevant strategy before deciding to use/create any Grid Trading Strategy.
"

"<hl1>Time-Weighted Average Price Algorithm (TWAP) and Volume-Weighted Average Price Algorithm (VP)</hl1>
Users may be permitted to submit orders for certain transactions based on the use of a Time-Weighted Average Price Algorithm (TWAP) and/or Volume-Weighted Average Price Algorithm (VP) (together, “TWAP and/or VP Orders”).
The risks associated with any TWAP and/or VP Order reside with User, not Binance. In particular, User shall be responsible for setting all relevant parameters of any TWAP and/or VP Order.
"

User acknowledges that Binance does not guarantee the full execution of any TWAP and/or VP Order and that the execution of any TWAP and/or VP Order is based on factors outside of Binance’s control. For example, if the market price of the relevant Digital Asset(s) referenced by any TWAP and/or VP Order moves considerably or liquidity is insufficient during the execution of a TWAP and/or VP Order, the algorithm may not achieve full completion.

"Further, if the market becomes distressed, the algorithm may fail to complete the TWAP and/or VP Order before the specified end time. Thus, execution of any TWAP and/or VP Order is and will always be liquidity-dependent with no guarantee for best price execution or execution of the order in full.
User acknowledges that Binance employs multiple risk mitigation strategies, including manual and automated circuit breakers, as well as kill-switch controls."

"These features can activate in the event of market disruption and/or systems failure, potentially canceling any TWAP and/or VP Order early before the order has been fully filled. Binance shall not be liable for any loss incurred by User due to the cancellation or failure to execute a TWAP and/or VP Order, whether partially or fully.
"

"No representation is being made or implied that submitting any TWAP and/or VP Order will guarantee a better overall execution price than one or more regular market orders. User is responsible for ensuring that User fully understands the risks associated with any TWAP and/or VP Order execution and for conducting thorough due diligence to ensure that this feature is suitable for them.
"

"<hl1>Rebalancing Bot</hl1>
User may be permitted to use the Rebalancing Bot service available through the Binance Platform to create a trading strategy to automatically execute spot transactions based on certain parameters as selected by User (each, a “Rebalancing Bot Strategy”). User may create a Rebalancing Bot Strategy by selecting applicable trading parameters, confirming or amending the preset category portfolios, and setting applicable rebalancing parameters. Any investment decision, portfolio selection, and parameter selection, in all cases, will be made solely by User."

"
By providing the Rebalancing Bot service, Binance does not determine the suitability of any portfolio or Rebalancing Bot parameter for User, regardless of whether such portfolio or parameter is suggested or pre-populated on the Platform or independently populated by User."

"Furthermore, Binance makes no representation or warranty that any Rebalancing Bot Strategy will perform as expected or be profitable for User. Any risk associated with a Rebalancing Bot Strategy resides solely with User. Binance shall not be responsible for any losses incurred in connection with any Rebalancing Bot Strategy.
User acknowledges that past performance of a Rebalancing Bot Strategy is not indicative of future results and agrees that the future performance of any Rebalancing Bot Strategy may not be profitable or equal to past performance.
"

"The Trading Bots that Binance may make available to Users include (but shall not be limited to): Spot Grid Trading, Futures Grid Trading, Time-Weighted Average Price (TWAP) and Volume-Weighted Average Price (VP) algorithmic trading tools, and Rebalancing Bot (each as described further below).
"

"Transactions entered into via a Rebalancing Bot Strategy may incur trading fees. User should consider the impact of trading fees on the performance of the relevant portfolio before deciding to use the Rebalancing Bot and setting any relevant parameters.
Category portfolios (referred to on the Platform as “AI Rebalance”) are generated based on relevant Digital Assets’ categories and market caps. Binance assigns one or more categories to each Digital Asset based on the main characteristics of that particular Digital Asset and its associated project."

For category portfolios, Binance compiles preset portfolios for certain Digital Asset categories, encompassing the Digital Assets that make up the top 30%% of the relevant category’s total market cap. The number of Digital Assets in a category portfolio will be between 2 and 10. This number depends on the market dynamics within the relevant category. Binance reserves the right to change the methodology for assigning categories and compiling category portfolios at any time at its sole discretion.

"
Binance makes no representation or warranty about the accuracy of the allocation of categories to Digital Assets or about the representativeness of any category portfolio of the associated sector.
"

"<hl1>Trading Bots Account and Trading Bots Orders</hl1>
"

Binance may create a separate account for orders submitted by User through the use of certain Trading Bots (each such account, a “Trading Bots Account”), in order to differentiate the resulting transactions from standard spot and futures transactions entered into by User through the Binance Platform other than through the use of such Trading Bots (which transactions will be recorded against User’s standard Spot or Futures Account (as applicable)).

"If a Trading Bots Account is set up for User, this will be set up automatically upon the entry by User into a Grid Trading Strategy or transaction (as applicable) pursuant to the use of the relevant Trading Bots, and details of such Trading Bots Account will be visible to User within the Binance Platform.
"

It is the responsibility of User to monitor each Trading Bots Account set up on its behalf and to ensure that sufficient Digital Assets are allocated to each Trading Bots Account to satisfy any payments due with respect to transactions recorded against such account (including, without limitation, payment of applicable fees and Margin Requirements with respect to the relevant transactions).

"User should monitor any Margin Calls and/or Liquidation notices sent by Binance with respect to its activity on the Platform to ensure that User understands which Account such Margin Calls and/or Liquidation notices relate to. Unless otherwise permitted by Binance, Digital Assets allocated to a User’s standard Spot and/or Futures Account will not be applied to satisfy Margin Calls or other payments due with respect to transactions recorded against a Trading Bots Account.
"

"<hl1>Digital Asset Risks</hl1>
Digital Asset prices are subject to high market risk and price volatility. Prices can fluctuate significantly on any given day. Due to these price fluctuations, your holdings may significantly increase or decrease in value at any given moment and you may not get back the amount you originally invested.
"

Therefore, User should not trade or invest money they cannot afford to lose. It is crucial that User fully understands the risks involved before deciding to utilize any Trading Bots in light of their own financial resources, level of experience, and risk appetite. If required, User should seek advice from an independent financial advisor. The actual returns and losses experienced by will vary depending on many factors, including, but not limited to, market behavior, market movement, and trade size. Past performance is not a guide to future performance.

"These Trading Bots Terms form part of, and shall be read together with, each of the <hl1>Binance Terms of Use</hl1>, the <hl2>Binance Spot Trading Terms of Use</hl2> and the <hl3>Binance Futures Service Agreement</hl3> (the “Service Agreements”). Capitalised terms used herein but not otherwise defined shall have the meaning given to them in the Service Agreements, as the context requires.
"
The value of your investments may go up or down. Binance does not provide financial or investment advice. For more information, see our <hl1>Terms of Use</hl1> and <hl2>Risk Warning</hl2>.

"<hl1>General disclaimer</hl1>
In offering Trading Bots to User, Binance is not providing any investment advice or recommending any particular Trading Bot, trading strategy and/or trading parameter as appropriate and/or suitable for User. User shall be solely responsible for determining whether or not to make use of any Trading Bots and for selecting an appropriate feature, trading strategy and/or parameters in light of their investment objectives, risk tolerance, financial situation and needs."

"Binance makes no representation or warranty as to the outcome of the use of any Trading Bot and will not be liable to User for any loss that might arise from or in connection with their use of any Trading Bot.
"

"<hl1>Spot Grid and Futures Grid Trading</hl1>
User may be permitted to create spot and/or futures grid trading strategies through the Binance Platform, so as to enable transactions in spot and/or futures products to be executed automatically by way of algorithm, based on certain parameters as selected by the User (each, a “Grid Trading Strategy”)."

"User acknowledges that the parameters selected will dictate the operation of the applicable Grid Trading Strategy and that User shall be entirely responsible for determining and confirming any parameters selected and/or any applicable execution methodology to be applied to any Grid Trading Strategy, regardless of whether such parameters and/or execution methodology are suggested or pre-populated on the Platform, replicated from an existing Grid Trading Strategy created by another User, or independently populated by User themselves.
"

User shall be responsible for ensuring that any Grid Trading Strategy selected or otherwise created is appropriate for User in light of their own investment objectives and will be consistent with any limitations or conditions that may apply to User’s with respect to the execution of any transaction.

"Use of any Grid Trading Strategy is at User’s own discretion and Binance does not determine the suitability of any Grid Trading Strategy or parameter for User or make any representation or warranty that any Grid Trading Strategy will be profitable. Any risk associated with a Grid Trading Strategy resides solely with User, not Binance.
User further acknowledges that the past performance of any Grid Trading Strategy is not indicative of future results and that the future performance of any Grid Trading Strategy may not be profitable or equal to past performances.
"

"UniMMR = Adjusted Equity / Maintenance Margin. UniMMR is an indicator of the liquidation risk of this arbitrage strategy. You might consider closing the arbitrage strategy earlier when UniMMR reaches high risk level. • Normal: UniMMR > 2, trade normally. • Low Risk: 1.5 < UniMMR <= 2, trade normally with low liquidation risk. • Medium Risk: 1.2 < UniMMR <= 1.5, trade normally with medium liquidation risk. • High Risk: 1.1 < UniMMR <= 1.2, trade restricted and can only place reduce only trade. • Liquidated: 1 < UniMMR <= 1.05, liquidation will be triggered. • Bankrupted: UniMMR <= 1, this strategy will be bankrupted."
Confirm to skip the set entry spread control and increase investment immediately.

"For positive carry portfolios (Buy Spot, Sell Future), the exit spread is calculated as (Spot Price - Futures Price)/Futures Price. The larger the spread, the higher the potential profit. We monitor the market in real time and only close positions when the spread reaches or exceeds your target.
Example: If you set a <hl1>2%</hl1> exit spread, and buy futures at <hl2>100 USDT</hl2> to close your position while selling spot at <hl3>102 USDT</hl3>, you earn a <hl4>+2%</hl4> exit spread profit via a buy-low-sell-high strategy."

"For reverse carry portfolios (Buy Futures, Sell Spot), the exit spread is calculated as (Futures Price - Spot Price)/Spot Price. The larger the spread, the higher the potential profit. We monitor the market in real time and only close positions when the spread reaches or exceeds your target.
Example: If you set a <hl1>2%</hl1> exit spread, and sell futures at <hl2>102 USDT</hl2> to close your position while buying back spot at <hl3>100 USDT</hl3>, you earn a <hl4>+2%</hl4> exit spread profit via a buy-low-sell-high strategy."

Trending Market Top 10 showcases the top 10 trending asset pairs, ranked according to the number of active strategies. The ranking is determined from the highest to the lowest number of running strategies. If two assets have the same number of running strategies, the one with the greater 24-hour change ranks higher. In cases where both the number of active strategies and the 24-hour change are identical, the ranking is determined randomly.

Volatility Top 10 presents the top 10 trending asset pairs based on volatility, a key metric for users employing Grid Trading Strategies. Rankings are determined by volatility, from highest to lowest. If two assets exhibit the same level of volatility, the asset with the higher 24-hour change ranks higher. If both the volatility and the 24-hour change are identical for two assets, the ranking is determined randomly.

%1$s The Trailing Stop Price is %2$s %3$s. Your Grid will run within %4$s - %5$s %6$s.

For example: The Initial Upper Limit is 21000 and the Initial Lower Limit is 20000. When the market price rises above 21500, the first trail up is triggered and the whole grid moves one step up. In this case, each price step is 500, and after the trail up has been processed the new Upper Limit is 21500 and the New Lower Limit is 21000. As the market price keeps rising, the grid price range will trail up accordingly.
Never miss out on upward market trends. Grid trading now supports automatic upward trailing when prices rise.

This ratio serves as a reference; always check the grid's actual status for accurate information.
• 1.5≤ BRR, Low Risk • 1.2≤ BRR <1.5 Medium Risk • 1.0≤ BRR <1.2 High Risk, system will send the margin not enough notification • BRR <1.0, the grid will be expired due to insufficient margin"

"When the Current Price (A) drops to the order’s Limit Price (C) or below, the order will execute automatically. The order will be filled immediately if the buying price is above or equal to the current price. Therefore, the buying price of limit orders must be below the current price.
For example: 1) The current price in the above graph is 2400 (A). If a new buy/limit order is placed with Limit price 1500 (C), the order will not execute until the price drops to %@.
2) Instead, if the buy/limit order is placed with Limit price %@, which is above the current price, the order will be filled with the rival price immediately. And the executed price is around 2400, not 3000."

When the Current Price (A) drops to the order’s Limit Price (C) or below, the order will execute automatically. The order will be filled immediately if the buying price is above or equal to the current price. Therefore, the buying price of limit orders must be below the current price.

"For example: 1) The current price in the above graph is 2400 (A). If a new buy/limit order is placed with a limit price of 1500 (C), the order will not execute until the price drops to %@.
2) Instead, if the buy/limit order is placed with a limit price of %@, which is above the current price, the order will be filled with the counterparty price immediately. The executed price is around 2400, not 3000."

"For example: 1) The current price in the above graph is 2,400 (A). If a new buy/limit order is placed with Limit price 1,500 (C), the order will not execute until the price drops to %@.
2) Instead, if the buy/limit order is placed with Limit price %@, which is above the current price, the order will be filled at the market price immediately. The executed price will be around 2,400, not 3,000."
A Limit order is to buy or sell at a specific price or better. Limit orders are not guaranteed to execute.

"When the Current Price (A) increases to the order’s Limit Price (B) or above, the order will execute automatically. The order might be filled immediately if the selling price is below or equal to the current price. Therefore, the selling price of limit orders must be above the current price.
For example: 1) The current price in the above graph is 2400 (A), if a new sell/limit order is placed with Limit Price 3000 (B), the order will not execute until the price increases to %@.
2) Instead, if the sell/limit order is placed with Limit Price %@, which is below the current price, the order would be filled with the rival price immediately; the filled price is around 2400, not 1500."

When the Current Price (A) increases to the order’s Limit Price (B) or above, the order will execute automatically. The order might be filled immediately if the selling price is below or equal to the current price. Therefore, the selling price of limit orders must be above the current price.

"For example: 1) The current price in the above graph is 2400 (A), if a new sell/limit order is placed with a limit price of 3000 (B), the order will not execute until the price increases to %@.
2) Instead, if the sell/limit order is placed with a limit price of %@, which is below the current price, the order would be filled with the counterparty price immediately. The filled price is around 2400, not 1500."

"For example: 1) The current price in the above graph is 2,400 (A), if a new sell/limit order is placed with Limit Price 3,000 (B), the order will not execute until the price increases to %@.
2) Instead, if the sell/limit order is placed with Limit Price %@, which is below the current price, the order would be filled at the market price immediately; the filled price is around 2,400, not 1,500."

Note: 1) For buy orders, the average filled price might be a bit higher than current price. And for sell orders, the average filled price might be a bit lower than current price.

"The Stop Price(B) should be higher than current price for buy orders, and the Limit Price(C) is supposed to be lower than current price.
Note: 1) The Stop Limit order is supposed be triggered when price goes up to %@, and the Limit order will be canceled at the same time. %@
2) On the contrary, if the price drops down to %@, the Limit order would execute automatically, and the Stop Limit order is supposed to be canceled. %@"

An OCO (One-Cancels-the-Other) order contains a limit order and a stop limit order. When either of the orders is triggered, the other order will be canceled. And if either of the orders is canceled, the other order will be canceled as well.

An OCO (One-Cancels-the-Other) order contains a Limit order and a Stop Limit (or Stop Market) order. When either of them is triggered, the other order will be canceled. Additionally, if either order is canceled, the other one will be canceled as well.

"The Stop Price(C) should be lower than current price for sell orders, and the Limit Price(B) is supposed to be higher than current price.
Note: 1) The Stop Limit order is supposed be triggered when price drops down to %@, and the Limit order will be canceled at the same time. %@
2) On the contrary, if the price goes up to %@, the Limit order would execute automatically, and the Stop Limit order is supposed to be canceled. %@"
A stop-limit order is a order that has both a stop price and a limit price. When the stop price is reached, it triggers the limit order.

"The current price is 2400 (A). The stop price of the stop limit order can be above the current price such as 3000 (B), or below the current price such as 1500 (C). Once the price goes up to 3000 (B) or drops down to 1500 (C), the stop limit order triggers, and the limit order will be activated automatically.
Note: 1) Limit price can be above or below stop price for both buy and sell orders. For example, %@ is able to combine with a lower %@, or a higher %@.
2) Limit order is invalid before the stop price is triggered, including when the limit price is reached ahead of the stop price.
3) When the stop price is reached, it only indicates that a limit order is activated and will be submitted to the market, rather than the limit order being filled immediately. The limit order will execute with its own rules. %@"

"The current price is 2,400 (A). The stop price of the stop limit order can be above the current price such as 3,000 (B), or below the current price such as 1,500 (C). Once the price goes up to 3,000 (B) or drops down to 1,500 (C), the stop limit order triggers, and the limit order will be activated automatically.
Note: 1) Limit price can be above or below stop price for both buy and sell orders. For example, %@ is able to combine with a lower %@, or a higher %@.
2) Limit order is invalid before the stop price is triggered, including when the limit price is reached ahead of the stop price.
3) When the stop price is reached, it only indicates that a limit order is activated and will be submitted to the market, rather than the limit order being filled immediately. The limit order will execute with its own rules. %@"

"The current price is 2400 (A). At this point, place a Trailing Stop Order. For buy, the activation price (B) needs to be lower than the current price (A). If the lowest market price has reached or exceeded the activation price (B)，and then rebound rate is greater than or equal to the trailing delta (C), this triggers the order to be executed as a limit order (D).
For example: 1）The current price in the above graph is 2400 (A). A new buy trailing stop order is placed with activation price 1500 (B), trailing delta 5% (C), limit price 1600 (D).
2）When the price rises, the buy trailing stop order will not take effect. Only when the price drops, and the lowest market price has reached or exceeded the activation price 1500 (B), one of the conditions of trailing stop order is satisfied.
3）Then rebound rate is greater than or equal to the trailing delta 5% (C), which is C=Market Lowest Price*(1+5%), two conditions of trailing stop order are satisfied. This triggers the order to be executed as a limit order, the limit price is 1600 (D)."

"The Activation Price (B) is optional. If set, it should be lower than the Current Price (A), when the Activation Price (B) is met and the rebound rate is greater than or equal to the trailing delta, a Limit (D) or Market order at price C will be submitted.
For example: 1) The current price in the above graph is 1700 (A). A new buy Trailing Stop order is created with an Activation Price of 1500 (B), a trailing delta of 10%, and a limit price of 1450 (D). The limit price can be any value, here we use 1450 as an example.
2）When the market price reaches the Activation Price of 1500 (B), one condition of the trailing stop order is satisfied. The second condition is satisfied when the price drops to 1400 (Lowest Market Price) and then starts to rise, the rebound rate is greater than or equal to the trailing delta of 10%, the price will reach price C = 1400 * (1 + 10%) = 1540. This triggers the submission of the Limit order at 1450 (D) to the order book.
3) If no limit price of 1450 (D) is set, a Market order will be preferred. Once the second condition is met, a market order will be submitted and will fill immediately at the market price."

"The Activation Price (B) is optional. If set, it should be lower than the Current Price (A). When the Activation Price (B) is met and the rebound rate is greater than or equal to the trailing delta, a Limit (D) or Market order at price C will be submitted.
For example: 1) The current price in the above graph is 1,700 (A). A new buy Trailing Stop order is created with an Activation Price of 1,500 (B), a trailing delta of 10%, and a limit price of 1,450 (D). The limit price can be any value, here we use 1,450 as an example.
2) When the market price reaches the Activation Price of 1,500 (B), one condition of the trailing stop order is satisfied. The second condition is satisfied when the price drops to 1,400 (Lowest Market Price) and then starts to rise, the rebound rate is greater than or equal to the trailing delta of 10%, the price will reach price C = 1,400 * (1 + 10%) = 1,540. This triggers the submission of the Limit order at 1,600 (D) to the order book.
3) If no limit price of 1,450 (D) is set, a Market order will be preferred. Once the second condition is met, a market order will be submitted and will fill immediately at the market price."

"Trailing Stop orders allow traders to send a pre-set order to the market when a market swing takes place. When the latest price reaches the highest/lowest price (1 ± trailing delta) after an order is created, this triggers the order to be submitted as a Limit/Market order.
The Activation Price is one of the trigger conditions for a Trailing Stop order. If no activation price is set, the last price will be used by default. The condition is considered satisfied only if the market price reaches or exceeds the Activation Price after the Trailing Stop order is created.
The Trailing Delta is another trigger condition for a Trailing Stop order. Even if the Activation Price condition is met, the Trailing Stop order will only take effect when the rebound rate of the highest/lowest market price is greater than or equal to the trailing delta. The trailing delta ranges from 0.1% to 20.0%."

"The current price is 2400 (A). At this point, place a Trailing Stop Order. For sell, the activation price (B) needs to be higher than the current price (A). If the highest market price has reached or exceeded the activation price (B)，and then rebound rate is greater than or equal to the trailing delta (C), this triggers the order to be executed as a limit order (D).
For example: 1）The current price in the above graph is 2400 (A). A new sell trailing stop order is placed with activation price 3000 (B), trailing delta 5% (C),limit price 2800 (D).
2）When the price drops, the sell trailing stop order will not take effect. Only when the price rises, and the highest market price has reached or exceeded the activation price 3000 (B), one of the conditions of trailing stop order is satisfied.
3）Then rebound rate is greater than or equal to the trailing delta 5% (C), which is C=Market Highest Price*(1-5%), two conditions of trailing stop order are satisfied. This triggers the order to be executed as a limit order, the limit price is 2800 (D)."

"The Activation Price (B) is optional. If set, it should be higher than the Current Price (A), when the Activation Price (B) is met and the rebound rate is greater than or equal to the trailing delta, a Limit (D) or Market order at price C will be submitted.
For example: 1) The current price in the above graph is 2000 (A). A new sell Trailing Stop order is created with an Activation Price of 3000 (B), a trailing delta of 10%, and a limit price of 3100 (D). The limit price can be any value, here we use 3100 as an example.
2）When the market price reaches the Activation Price of 3000 (B), one condition of the trailing stop order is satisfied. The second condition is satisfied when the price rises to 3200 (Highest Market Price) and then starts to drop, the rebound rate is greater than or equal to the trailing delta of 10%, the price will reach price C = 3200 * (1 - 10%) = 2880. This triggers the submission of the Limit order at 3100 (D) to the order book.
3) If no limit price of 3100 (D) is set, a Market order will be preferred. Once the second condition is met, a market order will be submitted and will fill immediately at the market price."

"The Activation Price (B) is optional. If set, it should be higher than the Current Price (A). When the Activation Price (B) is met and the rebound rate is greater than or equal to the trailing delta, a Limit (D) or Market order at price C will be submitted.
For example: 1) The current price in the above graph is 2,000 (A). A new sell Trailing Stop order is created with an Activation Price of 3,000 (B), a trailing delta of 10%, and a limit price of 3,100 (D). The limit price can be any value, here we use 3,100 as an example.
2) When the market price reaches the Activation Price of 3,000 (B), one condition of the trailing stop order is satisfied. The second condition is satisfied when the price rises to 3,200 (Highest Market Price) and then starts to drop, the rebound rate is greater than or equal to the trailing delta of 10%, the price will reach price C = 3,200 * (1 - 10%) = 2,880. This triggers the submission of the Limit order at 3,100 (D) to the order book.
3) If no limit price of 3,100 (D) is set, a Market order will be preferred. Once the second condition is met, a market order will be submitted and will fill immediately at the market price."

"Trailing Stop orders allow traders to send a pre-set order to the market when a market swing takes place. When the latest price reaches the highest/lowest price (1 ± trailing delta) after an order is submitted, this triggers the order to be executed as a limit order.
Trailing Delta is one of the trigger conditions for Trailing Stop order. After the Activation Price is satisfied, if the rebound rate of the highest/lowest market price is greater than or equal to the trailing delta, the Trailing Stop Order will be executed. The trailing delta ranges from 0.1% to 20.0%.
Activation Price is one of the trigger conditions for Trailing Stop order. If no activation price is set, the activation price will be the last price by default. When the highest/lowest market price reaches or exceeds the Activation Price after the Trailing Stop order is submitted, the condition is considered to be satisfied."

"A Binance Option is a type of European Option contract which, unlike American style options, can only be exercised at expiry, but can be bought or sold at the current market price at any time prior to expiry.
Options trading is a highly risky endeavor with the potential for both great profits and significant losses.
The maximum loss of an Options buyer is the amount of premium paid to purchase the Option."

"An Options seller may however lose the entire amount of margin posted to collateralise its position and risks being subject to liquidation if sufficient margin is not maintained.
Options trading is restricted for users from certain regions. Only certain users will be eligible to act as Option Writers.
By trading Options on Binance, you will be subject to the terms of the Binance Options Service Agreement."
Click to see Options Trading Guide

"Binance Options is a type of European Option contract. Comparing to American Options, European Options can be exercised only at its expiration date, but can buy and sell at current market price anytime before expiration.
Option trading is a highly risky endeavor with the potential for both great profits and significant losses.
The maximum loss of the options buyer is the amount of options premium cost, and the options seller may lose the entire margin.
Options trading is restricted for users from certain regions."

"Look at the 1st Ask price (lowest sell side price on order book) for the buy order.
When the Current Price (A) drops to the order's Limit Price (C) or below, the order will execute automatically. The order will be filled immediately if the buying price is above or equal to the current price. Therefore, the buying price of limit orders must be below the current price."

"Look at the 1st Bid price (highest buy side price on order book) for the sell order.
When the Current Price (A) increases to the order's Limit Price (B) or above, the order will execute automatically. The order will be filled immediately if the selling price is below or equal to the current price. Therefore, the selling price of limit orders must be above the current price."

Best Bid Offer (BBO) is another form of limit order. It automatically places your limit buy order at the current best offer price or your limit sell order at the current best bid price. Traders who wish to get the best prices but also want to get their orders filled quickly can use the BBO.

When the current price (A) drops to the order’s limit price (C) or below, the order will execute automatically. The order will be filled immediately if the buying price is above or equal to the current price. Therefore, the buying price of limit orders should be below the current price.

For example: 1) The current price in the above graph is 2400 (A). If a new buy limit order is placed with a limit price of 1500 (C), the order will not execute until the price drops to %@. 2) However, if the buy/limit order is placed with a limit price of %@, which is above the current price, the order will be filled with the counterparty price immediately. The executed price will be around 2400, not 3000.

"When the current price (A) increases to the order's limit price (B) or above, the order will execute automatically. The order will be filled immediately if the selling price is below or equal to the current price. Therefore, the selling price of limit orders should be above the current price."

For example: 1) The current price in the above graph is 2400 (A). If a new sell/limit order is placed with a limit price of 3000 (B), the order will not execute until the price increases to %@. 2) However, if the sell/limit order is placed with a limit price of %@, which is below the current price, the order would be filled with the counterparty price immediately. The filled price will be around 2400, not 1500.
A limit order is an order to buy or sell at a specific price or better. Limit orders are not guaranteed to execute.
Win Rate = Winning Days / (Winning Days + Losing Days + Breakeven Days)
Lowest price that users are willing to sell for
Highest price users are willing to pay for

The profit and loss based on your estimate will be displayed here. Tap for details. Note: this calculation does not include the handling fee.

"If your prediction is incorrect, the maximum loss you may get on the expiration date will be displayed here.
The formula is: Max loss = 0 - Buying Cost Your buying cost is now based on %1$s, you can change it on the calculator.
Displayed as \"--\" when the calculation yields an invalid result or when there are missing parameters."

"If your prediction is correct, the profit you may earn on the expiration date will be displayed here.
The formula for a call option is: Possible Profit = Predicted Price - Strike - Buying Cost The formula for a put option is: Possible Profit = Strike - Predicted Price - Buying Cost Your buying cost is now based on %1$s, you can change it on the calculator.
Displayed as \"--\" when there are missing parameters."

The average price, also known as Options Premium, is the entry price of Options contracts. It is the amount paid by an investor to obtain the right, but not the obligation, to exercise Options contracts.

"The breakeven price is the target asset price for options holders to cover the premium cost by holding until expiration, without selling beforehand.
• Call Breakeven = Strike Price + Average Price / Contract Size • Put Breakeven = Strike Price - Average Price / Contract Size . Breakeven% = (Breakeven Price - Index Price) / Index Price
Contract size refers to the specification of Options contracts. For some assets, 1 contract is equal to 1 unit, while for others, 1 contract is equal to 100 units. Similar to CM contracts, the value of each contract can vary."

"As an European Options owner, Options cannot be exercised early. Before expiration, Options owners are still free to close an Option position at any time by reducing the position to zero. Options unrealized PnL is calculated with Options mark price and average entry price, without the underlying asset price being included.
• Call Unrealized PNL = (Mark Price - Average Price) * Size • Put Unrealized PNL = (Average Price - Mark Price) * Size"

"For example: If you hold a 0.1 BTC-230825-33000-C, with an average price of 400USDT. The price of BTC rises, and when the mark price reaches 500USDT, the unrealized PNL of the option you hold is [(500 − 400) × 0.1] = 10 USDT. Even if the BTCUSDT price reaches 36000, you sill can't exercise it before expiration."
ROI% = (Mark Price - Average Price) / Average Price
Available Size = Position Size - Size of Close Position Open Orders
This is estimated PnL based on pre-set limit price excluding fee. Actual result may be different depending on actual filled price and fee charged.
Market Value = Options Mark Price x Size
ROI% = (Mark Price - Average Price) / Average Price

The projected Settlement Price to exercise the options, which is the arithmetic mean of the underlying asset Price Index during the last 1 hour before expiration.
Underlying asset Price Index. The arithmetic mean of Price Index in the last 30 mins before expiration will be used to settle the Options.

"The current best ask price on the order book is 1.9 USDT for ETH options, with a total of 19.62 contracts available. Depending on the Time-In-Force (TIF) parameter selected by the user, different order outcomes will be generated.
For example: Place an FoK order for 20 contracts of ETH call Options at a limit price of $1.9. Since the best price available is 1.9, which is only sufficient for 19.62 contracts out of the 20 contracts, the entire order will be canceled. Conversely, if the best price exceeds 20 contracts, the entire order will be filled."
Fill or Kill (FOK) orders must be immediately and fully executed at the order price or better, otherwise, they will be completely canceled.

"The current best ask price on the order book is 1.9 USDT for ETH Options, with a total of 19.62 contracts available. Depending on the Time-In-Force (TIF) parameter selected by the user, different order outcomes will be generated.
For example: Place a GTC order for 20 contracts of ETH call Options at a limit price of $1.9, with 19.62 contracts to be executed immediately and the remaining 0.38 contracts to remain valid until executed or manually canceled."
Good Till Canceled (GTC) orders will remain valid until they are fully executed or manually canceled.

"The current best ask price on the order book is 1.9 USDT for ETH options, with a total of 19.62 contracts available. Depending on the Time-In-Force (TIF) parameter selected by the user, different order outcomes will be generated.
For example: Place an IOC order to buy 20 contracts of ETH call Options at a limit price of $1.9. The user will buy 19.62 contracts of ETH call Options, and the remaining 0.38 contracts will be canceled simultaneously when the 19.62 contracts are executed."
Immediate or Cancel (IOC) orders must be partially filled immediately at limit price or better, and the unfilled amount will be canceled.
The maximum number of contracts you can place order given your wallet balance available and positions owned.

This is estimated implied volatility based on your order price. IV will change constantly as index price changes or as time gets closer to expiration.

"Breakeven Price refers to the average cost price of the crypto held in the Spot Wallet, based on data as far back as June 24, 2020. If users have been holding the crypto before this date, the price on June 24, 2020 will be taken as the initial cost. As for users who begin to hold the crypto after this date, the cost price will be calculated based on their latest holding. Calculation method: (Market price of the crypto when quantity increased x amount of increased quantity - market price of the crypto when quantity decreased x amount of decreased quantity) / (amount of increased quantity - amount of decreased quantity) As the calculation is based on the changes to crypto quantity in the Spot Wallet, there is no guarantee that the data is absolutely accurate."

"Recently, online scams have become more serious. Scammers may <font color='#F6465D'>pretend</font> to be Binance Customer Support and direct you to transfer your assets from Binance to their fraudulent addresses under the pretext of <font color='#F6465D'>high returns</font>, <font color='#F6465D'>vouchers</font> ,or <font color='#F6465D'>Anti-Money</font> Laundering regulations. Aside from Customer Support on the Binance app or website, Binance will not contact you using any other instant messenger. If you encounter the above situation, please terminate all transactions."

"Recently, <font color='#F6465D'>online scams</font> have become more serious. Scammers may use lower than market rate priced products to attract you to make payment on their fake online malls/websites. However, scammers would either deliver cheap <font color='#F6465D'>knock-offs</font> or <font color='#F6465D'>don't deliver</font> the products. Scamers may also ask you to pay additional fees for shipping or <font color='#F6465D'>customs</font> inspections. If you encounter the above situation, please terminate all transactions."

"Recently, <font color='#F6465D'>online scams</font> have become more serious. Scammers may contact you via <font color='#F6465D'>online dating</font> platforms to quickly gain your trust. Thereafter, scammers would claim they had found platform loopholes or <font color='#F6465D'>high returns</font> projects, and they would provide screenshots of their investment returns to attract you to transfer assets to their fraudulent addresses/fake trading platform. Initially, scammers may send you rebates to deceive you to invest more funds, however later they would <font color='#F6465D'>run off</font> with your funds. If you encounter the above situation, please terminate all transactions."

"Recently, <font color='#F6465D'>online scams</font> have become more serious. Scammers may use <font color='#F6465D'>high returns, free gifts</font>, online <font color='#F6465D'>part-time jobs</font>, and low-priced commodities as bait to attract you to transfer funds to their fraudulent addresses/fake trading platform. In order to gain your trust, scammers may also pretend to be customer service, <font color='#F6465D'>financial advisors</font>, etc. To further prove their project’s authenticity, they may allow you to withdraw successfully with a small amount initially. Once you transfer a large sum of funds, you may find yourself unable to withdraw anymore. Besides, scammers may ask you to pay <font color='#F6465D'>audit fees/taxes</font> before withdrawals can be made. If you encounter the above situation, please terminate all transactions."

"Recently, <font color='#F6465D'>online scams</font> have become more serious. Scammers may pretend to be event organizers and use <font color='#F6465D'>free</font> crypto/voucher/airdrop as bait, and attract you to pay <font color='#F6465D'>commissions</font>/cash deposits/activation fees, etc., and direct you to withdraw assets to their fraudulent addresses. In order to gain your trust, scammers may add you to a group chat, and their <font color='#F6465D'>accomplices</font> will claim to have successfully received the free gift. If you encounter the above situation, please terminate all transactions."

"Recently, <font color='#F6465D'>online scams</font> have become more serious. Scammers may use <font color='#F6465D'>high returns</font> as bait to attract you to transfer assets to their fraudulent addresses/<font color='#F6465D'>fake trading platform</font>. In order to gain your trust, you may withdraw successfully with <font color='#F6465D'>a small amount</font>. Once you transfer a large sum of funds, you may find yourself unable to withdraw anymore. Under the pretext of <font color='#F6465D'>taxes/audit fees/Anti-Money Laundering</font> regulations, etc., scammers would ask you to transfer more funds to them. If you encounter the above situation, please terminate all transactions."

"Recently, <font color='#F6465D'>online scams</font> have become more serious. Scammers may invite you to become a merchant on their fake online mall and they would create <font color='#F6465D'>fake orders</font> to make it look like you are making a profit. Thereafter, scammers would direct you to transfer assets to their fraudulent address under the pretext of <font color='#F6465D'>cash deposits</font> or <font color='#F6465D'>cash advances</font>. However after the transfer, you may find yourself unable to withdraw any profit from the fake mall. If you encounter the above situation, please terminate all transactions."

"Recently, <font color='#F6465D'>online scams</font> have become more serious. Scammers may use online <font color='#F6465D'>part-time jobs</font> offering high pay with little commitment or effort. In order to gain your trust, you may withdraw successfully from the platform with <font color='#F6465D'>a small amount</font>. Once you transfer a large sum of funds, you may find yourself unable to withdraw anymore. To deceive you into transfering more funds, scammers will fabricate a \"<font color='#F6465D'>multi-order</font>\" model, and encourage you to take loans or borrow from your friends to complete the remaining tasks before funds can be withdrawn. If you encounter the above situation, please terminate all transactions."

"Recently, <font color='#F6465D'>online scams</font> have become more serious. Scammers may <font color='#F6465D'>pretend</font> to be official customer service, banks, customs, Anti-Money Laundering organizations and direct you to transfer your assets to their designated secure addresses, by either claiming that the assets would be <font color='#F6465D'>returned</font> to you after their investigation, or claiming that the assets were charged for various <font color='#F6465D'>fees/taxes</font>. If you encounter the above situation, please terminate all transactions."

"Recently, <font color='#F6465D'>online scams</font> have become more serious. Scammers may use high returns as a bait to attract you to transfer assets to their fraudulent addresses/<font color='#F6465D'>fake trading platform</font>. In order to gain your trust, scammers would provide <font color='#F6465D'>rebates</font> to you initially and inform you to <font color='#F6465D'>build a team</font> of friends/relatives to gain more rebate/returns. This is a typical <font color='#F6465D'>Ponzi scheme</font>. Once your team transfers a large sum of funds to scammers, you may find yourself unable withdraw anymore. In order to induce you to transfer more funds, scammers would claim that you need to pay <font color='#F6465D'>audit fees/taxes</font>, etc. If you encounter the above situation, please terminate all transactions."

"Recently, <font color='#F6465D'>online scams</font> have become more serious. Scammers may first complete several P2P/C2C transactions with you to gain your trust. Thereafter, before a transaction was confirmed by your bank, scammers claim to have an emergency and provide a <font color='#F6465D'>screenshot</font> of a bank remittance voucher to prove that they had transferred funds to your account, and requested you to transfer your assets to their addresses. Scammers may have <font color='#F6465D'>forged</font> the bank remittance voucher or <font color='#F6465D'>cancel</font> it after receiving your assets, thereby causing financial losses to you. If you're conducting a P2P/C2C trade, please make sure to confirm the receipt with your bank before transferring your assets."

"<font color='#F6465D'>In the past 7 days, more than 5 people have reported this address as fraudulent</font>. Please terminate your transaction. Scammers will gain your trust by sending small refunds up front, but once they learn that you know you're being scammed, they'll <font color='#F6465D'>change the withdrawal address</font> and let you try again. They may also threaten that your initial deposit/investment will not be returned to you unless you transfer the required amount, complete a number of tasks, or pay <font color='#F6465D'>audit fees/taxes</font>, etc."
